The  goal  of  the  Project  is  to  promote  regional  cooperation  and 
sustainable  economic  growth  in  Mongolia.  The  purpose  is  to 
increase  the  efficiency  and  safety  of  domestic  and  international 
transit  traffic  between  the  PRC  and  Russia  through  Mongolia’s 
north-south  road  transport  corridor.  The  Project  comprises  five 
components: 
 
 

(i)  construction of 428 kilometers (km) of a two-lane, asphalt  
concrete  road  between  Choyr  and  the  PRC  border  in 
 
Zamyn-Uud  
 

(ii)  implementation of a cross-border road transport facilitation 
 

plan 

(iii)  improvement of road safety 

(iv) implementation  of  an  area  development  program  that 
includes  (a)  constructing  four  access  roads  totaling  about 
 
34  km  to  connect  Erdene,  Orgon,  and  Saynshand; 
 
(b)  establishing  a  pilot  roadside  station;  (c)  training  local 
 
laborers  on  road  construction  and  maintenance;  and 
 
(d) enhancing stakeholder participation 
 

(v)  technical  assistance  for  awareness  and  prevention  of 
  HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking  on  the  north-south  road 
 

corridor

project implementation.

 The Project will benefit the people living along the road corridor in 
Mongolia  (about  48,400  based  on  the  2003  population),  road 
transport  operators  and  users,  construction  companies,  traders, 
and other people who derive income from expanded traffic, trade, 
and  investment  in  the  region.  The  major  benefits  will  be  in  the 
form  of  improved  trade  and  transit,  and  significantly  reduced 
transaction  costs  among  the  PRC,  Mongolia,  Russia,  and  other 
trading  partners.  Major  direct  benefits  will  be  lower  transport 
costs,  faster  and  more  reliable  road  transport  services,  and  job 
and  income  opportunities  created  during  project  implementation 
(i.e.,  use  of  local  labor  and  construction  materials)  or  along  the 
project  road  after  project  completion.  The  Project  is  expected  to 
create  about  1,800  jobs  on  road  construction  and  maintenance, 
and  income  amounting  to  MNT3.4  billion  ($2.9  million)  for 
Mongolians. The Project’s economic internal return is estimated at 
29.7%.  Indirect  benefits  will  be  increased  business  and  job 
opportunities  in  the  PRC,  Mongolia,  and  Russia,  which  have 
backward or forward linkages to the Project. 
 
The  Project  has  three  potential  risks.  First,  implementation  may 
be  delayed  due  to  DOR’s  limited  experience  in  managing 
construction of a relatively long road. This risk will be mitigated by 
provision of consulting services and advance procurement action. 
Second, counterpart funds may not be provided on a timely basis. 
ADB  will  work  closely  with  the  Government  to  ensure  that 
sufficient  counterpart  funds  for  the  Project  are  allocated  in  a 
timely  manner.  Third,  maintenance  of  the  project  road  after 
completion  may  be  inadequate  due  to  insufficient  funding. 
This  risk  will  be  mitigated  mainly  through  the  establishment  of  a 
facility  in  Zamyn-Uud  to  collect  vehicles  fees  beginning  in  2009, 
with  fee  revenues  to  be  allocated  to  the  Road  Fund  for 
maintaining the project road. The fee revenues will be sufficient to 
cover the annual maintenance cost of the project road to ensure 
sustainability. 
 
The  proposed  TA  for  $350,000  equivalent,  to  be  financed  from 
ADB’s TA funding program on a grant basis, will accompany the 
loan to create public awareness and take preventive measures to 
reduce  the  risks  of  HIV/AIDS  transmission  and  human  trafficking 
on the north-south road corridor.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Mongolia for the Regional Road Development Project (the Project). The report also describes 
proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Awareness  and  Prevention  of  HIV/AIDS1  and  Human 
Trafficking, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated 
to me by the Board, will approve the TA.  
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES2 

2. 
The Project will develop the remaining section of Mongolia’s north-south road transport 
corridor  between  Choyr  and  the  border  with  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  in  Zamyn-
Uud. The Project is classified as a regional project for the following reasons. First, the corridor 
constitutes a part of the Asian highway network (Route 3)3 linking the road systems of the PRC 
and the Russian Federation (Russia) and passing through major economic centers of Mongolia. 
Second,  regional  traffic  (i.e.,  traffic  from  or  to  Mongolia  and  transit  traffic  via  Mongolia)  is 
projected  to  account  for  about  75%  of  total  corridor  traffic  during  2009−2025;  therefore  the 
corridor will serve as an important route for domestic and international transit traffic, promoting 
trade  and  reducing  transaction  costs  among  countries  in  the  region.  Third,  the  Project  will 
complement ongoing negotiations on the draft Transit Traffic Framework Agreement among the 
PRC,  Mongolia,  and  Russia,  which  are  expected  to  be  concluded  soon.4  The  Mongolian 
Government  has  accorded  the  Project  high  priority  and  has  sought  assistance  from  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The project framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

3. 
Mongolia’s road sector is underdeveloped and is unable to fulfill its objective of fostering 
economic and social development. A detailed road sector analysis is in Appendix 2. The main 
features of the sector are summarized as follows: 
 

The  country  has  a  road  network  of  about  49,250  kilometers  (km),  comprising 
11,063 km of state roads and 38,187 km of local roads. Only 12% of the roads 
(1,670  km)  are  paved,  13%  (1,800  km)  are  gravel,  and  75%  are  earth  roads. 
Road density (0.03 km per km2) and the share of paved roads (3.4%) are low. 

Road transport carries only about 3% of freight in ton-kilometers (TKM) and less 
than 20% of passengers in passenger-kilometers (PKM). 

Registered vehicles (private vehicles in particular) increased rapidly by about 6% 
per  annum  during  1994–2003  due  to  economic  recovery  and  progress  on  the 
transition  to  a  market-based  system.  In  2003  Mongolia  had  138,307  registered 
vehicles with a ratio of 45.5 vehicles per 1,000 persons, which was close to the

(iv) 

Road sector funding through the Road Fund6 has been inadequate, ranging from 
45  to  79%  of  the  amount  needed  by  the  Department  of  Roads  (DOR).  Funding 
for  road  maintenance  is  even  limited,  accounting  for  about  25%  of  the  amount 
requested  by  DOR  and  less  than  0.2%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP). 
Inadequate road sector funding leads to deterioration of the road network and will 
not meet the needs of the reviving economy. 

(v) 

Road  accidents  have  risen  significantly  since  the  mid-1990s,  with  the  total 
number growing from 860 in 1995 to 5,553 in 2002. The fatality rate in 2002 was 
24 persons per 10,000 vehicles, higher than in many other Asian countries.7 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

4. 
The  key  problem  in  Mongolia’s  road  sector  is  underdevelopment  of  the  road  network, 
even taking into account the country’s low population density. Road density (0.03 km per km2) 
and the share of paved roads (3.4%) in Mongolia are both close to the low end of the countries 
in  the  world.8  The  share  of  freight  transport  by  road  is  also  lowest  among  the  transition 
economies of Eastern Europe and the Commonwealth of Independent States.9 Moreover, many 
paved and gravel roads are deteriorating and a large proportion remains impassable during the 
rainy or winter seasons due to inadequate maintenance. 
 
5. 
The  main  constraint  to  development  of  the  road  sector  is  inadequate  funding  (an 
assessment  of  the  road  sector  financial  management  is  in  Appendix  2).  A  World  Bank  study 
notes that for capital investment and maintenance, Mongolia’s road sector requires a minimum 
annual  funding  equivalent  to  2.4%  of  GDP  during  1999−2014.10  The  Road  Fund  has  failed  to 
receive  adequate  revenues  needed  for  the  road  sector,  and  actual  road  sector  funding  during 
1999−2003  accounted  for  less  than  1%  of  GDP.  Allocation  for  road  maintenance  has  been 
inadequate, despite some improvement in recent years. The share of funds allocated for road 
maintenance (less than 0.2% of GDP) in Mongolia is lower than in many other Asian countries.11 
Fiscal deficits of the Government (3.6% of GDP in 2003) and a high external debt (103.7% of 
GDP in 2003) are the primary factors limiting government funding for the road sector. Lack of an 
updated sector strategy exacerbates the problem because the Government sometimes fails to 
allocate limited financial resources to priority projects on the basis of the country’s development 
strategy and sound technical and economic analyses.

Government  funding  for  the  road  sector  will  likely  remain  inadequate  over  the  medium 
6. 
term,  given  the  continued  fiscal  deficits.  The  potential  of  private  financing  to  develop  road 
infrastructure is also limited, because the large capital investment requirements for developing 
road  infrastructure  are  generally  beyond  the  private  sector’s  present  capacity  to  mobilize 
resources.  Hence,  there  is  justification  for  external  aid  sources  including  ADB  to  continue 
assistance to the road sector of Mongolia, including financial support for the Project. The Project 
will develop the road infrastructure between Choyr and the PRC border in Zamyn-Uud and will 
have important implications for the following aspects. 
 
7. 
Access to World Markets. As a large landlocked country, Mongolia depends on its two 
neighborsthe  PRC  and  Russiafor  access  to  world  markets  and  economic  development.  
The PRC and Russia dominate Mongolia’s external trade and are major sources of its foreign 
direct  investment  (FDI).  In  particular,  the  PRC  is  Mongolia’s  largest  source  of  FDI,  its  largest 
market  for  exports,  and  second  largest  country  (after  Russia)  for  its  imports.12  Mongolia  also 
uses  the  port  of  Tianjin13  in  the  PRC,  the  closest  seaport,  for  access  to  the  markets  of  the 
United  States  and  other  countries  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  However,  the  lack  of  paved  roads 
leading  to  the  PRC  is  a  constraint.  The  majority  of  Mongolia’s  external  trade  is  carried  on  the 
existing  north-south  railway  line,  which  connects  Suhbaatar  at  the  border  with  Russia  and 
Zamyn-Uud at the border with the PRC. While the railway is suitable for carrying long haul and 
bulk cargoes, it is less flexible and responsive to the needs of private traders for smaller freight 
and  over  shorter  distances.14  Railway  transport  is  also  subject  to  the  problem  of  different 
gauges between Mongolia and the PRC. The Project will increase Mongolia’s access to world 
markets through the establishment of an all-weather road to link the highways of the PRC and 
Russia,15 and induce competition between railway and roads. 
 
8. 
Transit  Traffic.  Given  its  geographic  location,  Mongolia  can  serve  as  a  corridor  for 
transit  traffic  between  the  PRC  and  Russia.  The  north-south  road  corridor  from  Altanbulag  to 
Zamyn-Uud  through  Ulaanbaatar,  will  connect  the  Chinese  road  leading  to  the  port  of  Tianjin 
and the Russian road leading to Europe via the cities of Irkutsk and Novosibirsk, and thus can 
become an important transit route between the two neighbors. Transit traffic via this corridor is 
projected  to  grow  by  6−8%  per  annum  during  2009−2025,  from  25.1  million  to  90.5  million  in 
TKM  and  from  113.9  million  to  289.4  million  in  PKM.  By  providing  faster,  safer,  and  more 
reliable road transport, this corridor will not only increase the efficiency of transit traffic between 
the PRC and Russia via Mongolia, but also become a sustainable source of foreign exchange 
earnings for Mongolia. The importance of this corridor as a transit gateway and part of the Asian 
highway network is recognized by the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia 
and  the  Pacific  (UNESCAP).  With  ADB  assistance,  the  Altanbulag-Ulaanbaatar  section  was

14 For example, there is a shortage of rail wagons in Zamyn-Uud, so trucks that carry freight from the PRC often have 
to  wait  4  or  more  days  to  transship  the  freight  to  wagons  for  further  railway  transport  to  other  destinations  in 
Mongolia.  Moreover,  the  railway  does  not  unload  cargo  at  intermediate  stops  between  Zamyn-Uud  and 
Ulaanbaatar (e.g., Choyr and Saynshand), so traders have to either carry the goods in passenger compartments, 
or receive their cargo in Ulaanbaatar and then travel back to the ultimate destinations. 

15 With  the  construction  of  an  all-weather  road  between  Choyr  and  Zamyn-Uud,  the  transit  time  for  container 
movements between Tianjin and Ulaanbaatar will be reduced from the current 7−22 days to 3 days because trucks 
do not need to wait for wagons in Zamyn-Uud.  

 4

 

 

rehabilitated and the Nalayh-Choyr section is under construction.16 The Project will complete the 
remaining section of the corridor between Choyr and the border with the PRC. 
 
9. 
Poverty Reduction. Mongolia is a poor country: 35.6% of the population lives in poverty 
(1998) and per capita GDP is $505 (2003). The project feasibility study shows that about 10,500 
people (21.6% of the total population) in the project area are living in poverty. Poverty is largely 
income-based  and  mainly  due  to  the  lack  of  job  opportunities.  The  number  of  people 
unemployed in the project area was about 3,600 in 2002, with the unemployment rate at 18.4%. 
As about 57% of the population are 25 years or younger and many young people enter the labor 
market each year, the unemployment and poverty situation in the project area is grave. The lack 
of  paved  roads  between  Choyr  and  Zamym-Uud  hinders  investors  from  doing  business  in  the 
project  area  and  limits  local  communities’  access  to  markets  and  social  services.  The  Project 
will help tackle the poverty problem in the project area by improving the road infrastructure, so 
as to attract investments, create local jobs, and provide local communities with better access to 
markets and social services. 
 
Road  Safety.  Road  safety  is  becoming  a  serious  problem  in  Mongolia.  Poor  road 
10. 
conditions  are  among  the  major  factors  conducive  to  the  increase  in  road  accidents,  together 
with  poor  driving  skills,  high  vehicular  speeds,  intoxicated  driving,  and  technical  problems  of 
vehicles.  The  road  surface  is  deteriorating  and  some  sections  lack  road  safety  features  (e.g., 
markings, signage, and guardrails). The problem is exacerbated by weak enforcement of traffic 
safety  regulations  due  to  the  limited  capacity  of  the  Traffic  Police  Department  (TPD),  as  most 
traffic  police  officers  have  neither  appropriate  training  nor  adequate  monitoring  equipment.  
With  the  present  rate  of  increase  in  vehicle  ownership,  there  is  the  potential  for  more  road 
accidents. The Project will improve road safety by designing and constructing the project road 
and  access  roads  according  to  national  standards,  complemented  by  the  implementation  of  a 
road safety improvement component. 
 
The Government’s road sector strategy aims to improve the efficiency of road transport 
11. 
to facilitate the country’s economic and social development. The strategy focuses on (i) creating 
a  favorable  environment  for  developing  a  competitive  road  transport  industry,  (ii)  increasing 
investment  on  road  construction  and  rehabilitation  to  reduce  Mongolia’s  isolation  from  world 
markets and improve the accessibility of isolated communities within the country, (iii) increasing 
funding for road maintenance, (iv) improving the efficiency of state-owned transport enterprises, 
and (v) improving road safety. While progress has been made on creating a favorable climate 
for a competitive road transport industry, severe fiscal constraints have limited the progress on 
increasing  funding  for  road  construction  and  maintenance,  and  improving  road  safety. 
Moreover,  the  strategy  should  review  the  need  to  maintain  the  existing  road  network  in  areas 
with  low  population  densities.  A  Road  Master  Plan  prepared  with  ADB  assistance17  identified 
priority sections for investment and improvement, but the Master Plan needs updating as many 
priority  projects  identified  have  been  constructed  or  are  under  construction.  The  Government 
has accorded high priority to the Project and the construction of the east-west millennium road 
that links several aimag (province) centers with Ulaanbaatar. However, the millennium road has 
significant  implications  for  the  fiscal  stability  and  debt  sustainability  of  the  country,  and  is  a 
subject of ongoing dialogue between external aid agencies and the Government.

 5

The  main  objective  of  ADB’s  assistance  strategy  for  Mongolia  is  to  foster  pro-poor 
12. 
economic  growth  to  reduce  poverty.18  The  strategy  focuses  on  support  for  (i)  creating  an 
environment conducive to private sector-led growth, (ii) generating employment, (iii) maintaining 
standards of human development, (iv) strengthening and reforming the social protection system, 
and  (v)  undertaking  governance  reforms.  The  latest  country  strategy  and  program  update  for 
Mongolia19  indicates  that  roads  should  continue  to  be  among  the  strategic  focuses  of  ADB 
operations,  and  gives  priority  to  the  completion  of  the  north-south  road  corridor.  The  Project, 
which  is  included  in  the  assistance  program  for  2004,  is  supportive  of  the  objective  of  ADB’s 
country strategy and is consistent with its efforts for promoting regional cooperation, as it would 
contribute to increasing traffic, trade, and investment among countries in the region. 
 
13.  Mongolia’s road sector has received external assistance since 1991 (Appendix 3). ADB 
has approved two loans totaling $50 million and five TA grants totaling $3.3 million for improving 
the  north-south  road  corridor,  supporting  sector  reforms,  and  building  DOR’s  capacity.  
ADB  assistance,  which  helped  advance  its  road  sector  policy  and  institutional  reforms  in 
Mongolia, included (i) developing the Road Act and the Road Transport Act to lay the basis for a 
sector  policy  framework,  (ii)  formulating  the  Road  Master  Plan,  and  (iii)  establishing  the  Road 
Board  to  monitor  operation  of  the  Road  Fund.  However,  the  recommendations  of  the  ADB-
financed TAthat the Road Fund be used primarily for maintenance and that most of the Road 
Fund  revenues  come  from  road-user  charges  set  at  levels  reflecting  the  costs  that  vehicles 
impose on the road systemhave not been fully implemented.20 
 
14. 
ADB  assistance  has  been  complemented  by  activities  of  other  external  aid  agencies. 
The World Bank extended two credits totaling $64 million to upgrade part of the east-west road 
corridor,  improve  road  safety  and  maintenance,  and  train  DOR  staff.  The  Japan  International 
Cooperation  Agency  provided  grants  for  improving  roads  in  Ulaanbaatar  and  in  eastern 
Mongolia.  The  Kuwait  Fund  is  assisting  in  improving  the  Darhan-Erdenet-Bulgan  road.  
With  support  from  the  Nordic  Development  Fund,  the  Government  is  formulating  a  road 
maintenance  plan.  ADB  has  coordinated  closely  with  other  external  aid  agencies  in  the  road 
sector.  A  working  group  on  infrastructure,  cochaired  by  ADB  and  the  World  Bank,  was 
established in April 2004 to coordinate external assistance activities. ADB and the World Bank 
agreed  to  harmonize  their  respective  positions  on  road  sector  issues  and  jointly  assist  the 
Government to develop a transport sector strategy that would assess total funding requirements 
to maintain the existing road network, identify major funding constraints, and recommend how to 
address these constraints over the medium term. ADB also consults with UNESCAP regularly to 
maintain collaboration in the road sector. 
 
15. 
Lessons  Learned.  ADB’s  portfolio  performance  in  Mongolia’s  road  sector  has  been 
generally  satisfactory.  Evaluation  of  the  country  assistance  program  conducted  in  200221 
concluded that ADB’s road sector projects helped increase traffic counts and expand economic 
activities  in  the  project  road-influenced  areas.  The  first  road  project  for  rehabilitating  the 
Altanbulag-Ulaanbaatar  section  was  completed  in  2001  and  was  rated  as  highly  successful.22 
While  implementation  of  the  second  road  project  for  developing  the  Nalayh-Choyr  section 
experienced initial delays due to limited experience of the contractor and the executing agency,

 6

 

 

the pace of implementation has picked up and the Government and the contractor are working 
on the target of completing the project at the end of 2004 as scheduled. Nevertheless, the road 
projects supported by ADB and other external aid agencies in Mongolia and in the region have 
provided  four  major  lessons,  which  have  been  incorporated  into  the  design  of  this  Project.  
First,  loan  projects  involve  risks  of  implementation  delays  because  of  (i)  limited  experience  of 
implementing  agencies and  contractors;  (ii)  Mongolia’s  extreme  winter  conditions  that  limit  the 
annual  construction  season  to  only  6  months  (April−October),  which  means  that  even  minor 
delays  in  contractors’  mobilization  schedule  or  processing  of  project  documents  may  result  in 
slippage  of  1  year  in  project  implementation;  and  (iii)  the  complexity  of  resolving  cross-border 
issues.23 While DOR’s project management capacity has improved through training, it would be 
further strengthened by consulting services under the Project. Special attention will also be paid 
during the bidding process to ensure the recruitment of experienced civil works contractors. 
 
16. 
Second, the Government’s repeated difficulties in meeting funding requirements for road 
maintenance  through  the  state  budget  highlights  the  need  to  establish  a  sustainable  funding 
mechanism.  Since  the  Road  Fund  by  itself  is  not  a  guarantee  that  sufficient  funds  will  be 
provided  to  meet  the  needs  of  the  road  network,  the  Project  will  establish  a  facility  in  Zamyn-
Uud  to  collect  vehicle  fees,  with  fee  revenues  to  be  allocated  to  the  Road  Fund  for  road 
maintenance. The fee revenues generated are estimated to be sufficient not only to cover the 
annual  maintenance  cost  of  the  project  road,  but  also  to  contribute  for  maintenance  of  other 
priority  roads  in  the  country.  Third,  adequate  attention  should  be  paid  to  road  safety  issues 
when  formulating  and  implementing  road  projects.  While  road  safety  features  will  be 
incorporated into the project design, the Project includes a road safety improvement component 
(para.  22).  Fourth,  the  impact  of  road  infrastructure  projects  on  the  local  community  and  on 
poverty  reduction  should  be  strengthened.  The  Project  includes  an  area  development 
component  that  will  enhance  project  benefits  for  local  communities,  including  the  poor  (paras. 
23−27).  
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Objective 

The  goal  of  the  Project  is  to  promote  regional  cooperation  and  sustainable  economic 
17. 
growth  in  Mongolia.  The  purpose  is  to  increase  the  efficiency  and  safety  of  domestic  and 
international  transit  traffic  between  the  PRC  and  Russia  through  Mongolia’s  north-south  road 
transport  corridor.  The  project  area  covers  a  population  of  about  48,400  in  the  aimags  of 
Dornogovi and Govisumber in Mongolia. 
 
B. 

Components and Outputs 

The  Project  consists  of  five  components:  (i)  construction  of  the  project  road,  
18. 
(ii)  implementation  of  a  cross-border  road  transport  facilitation  plan,  (iii)  road  safety 
improvement, (iv) implementation of an area development  program, and (v) TA for awareness 
and prevention of HIV/AIDS and human trafficking on the north-south road corridor. 
 

                                                 
23 For example, it took more than 2 years before the Cross-Border Agreement between Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz

to  the  Republic  of  Kazakhstan  and  to  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  for  the  Almaty-Bishkek  Regional  Road  Rehabilitation 
Project. Manila. 

 

  

 

 7

1. 

Project Road 

19. 
The project road, about 428 km, extends from Choyr (the point where the ADB-assisted 
Second Roads Development Project ends) to the border with the PRC in Zamyn-Uud. The route 
between Choyr and Saynshand will run parallel to the railway line on the eastern side, while the 
route between Saynshand and Zamyn-Uud will lie on the western side of the railway line, with a 
railway level crossing in Saynshand. The project road will be designed according to Mongolian 
highway  design  standards.  The  Choyr-Zamyn-Uud  section  will  be  a  two-lane  paved  road  with 
7.0-meter (m)-wide pavement and  1.5 m shoulders. The section between Zamyn-Uud and the 
border  with  the  PRC  will  be  a  four-lane  paved  road  with  14.0  m  wide  pavement  and  2.0  m 
shoulders. Civil works costs are estimated at $50.1 million equivalent. 
 
As the project area is semiarid and sparsely vegetated steppe, vegetation will be planted 
20. 
along the project road for a length of 15−18 km at intervals within an approximate distance of 
130 km to serve as windbreaks to control snow and sand drifts. About $1 million equivalent will 
be allocated for vegetation planting. 
 

2. 

Cross-Border Road Transport Facilitation Plan 

21. 
The  plan  aims  to  promote  efficient  movement  of  vehicles  across  the  Mongolian-PRC 
border  (Appendix  4).  The  plan  comprises  the  Government’s  committed  actions,  within  the 
specific  time  frame,  to  (i)  develop  a  transit  traffic  framework  agreement  with  the  PRC  and 
Russia, (ii) establish regulations on cross-border vehicles according to international standards, 
(iii)  negotiate  with  the  PRC  on  increased  access  of  Mongolian  vehicles  to  PRC  territory,  
(iv) improve the road between Zamyn-Uud and the border with the PRC, (v) collect vehicle fees 
for road maintenance, (vi) enforce vehicle weight control, and (vii) establish emergency services 
for vehicles and passengers traveling on the north-south road corridor. The amount of $230,000 
equivalent will be allocated for consulting services to assist in implementing the plan. 
 

3. 

Road Safety Improvement 

22. 
This  component  comprises  (i)  installation  of  road  safety  features  (i.e.,  centerline 
markings,  reflectors  on  the  shoulders,  road  signs,  safety  barriers,  and  telephone  lines  for 
reporting  emergencies  along  the  road)  on  the  Altanbulag-Ulaanbaatar  section  ($350,000);  
(ii) independent road safety audit of the detailed design of the Project ($15,000); (iii) distribution 
of  pamphlets  and  posters  on  road  safety  to  raise  public  awareness;  (iv)  procurement  of  two 
patrol  vehicles  equipped  with  breath  analyzers  and  speed  monitoring  equipment  and  11  two-
way  communication  radios  ($63,200);  and  (v)  training  of  traffic  police  officers  on  traffic 
regulations and enforcement by an international specialist within 1 year before the project road 
is  opened  ($46,000).  The  component  will  complement  the  inclusion  of  safety  features  into  the 
design  of  the  project  road.  DOR  will  coordinate  with  TPD  on  training  the  traffic  police  officers, 
and  these  officers  will  then  deliver  road  safety  education  to  concerned  local  communities.  
The amount of $474,200 equivalent will be allocated for this component. 
 

4. 

Area Development 

23. 
This component is designed to ensure that the benefits generated from the project road 
are  shared  adequately  with  local  communities,  including  the  poor.  The  component  comprises  
(i) construction of access roads, (ii) establishment of roadside stations, (iii) local labors’ training 
on road construction and maintenance, and (iv) stakeholder participation. 
 

 8

 

 

Access  Roads.  Four  access  roads  totaling  34  km  will  be  constructed  to  facilitate  the 
24. 
movement  of  people  and  goods  between  towns  in  the  project  area  and  the  project  road.  
The four access roads comprise (i) a road from Erdene (10 km), (ii) a road from Orgon (20 km), 
and  (iii)  two  roads  from  Saynshand  (2  km  each).  The  roads  were  selected  with  stakeholder 
participation and consultation. The roads from Saynshand will be built to the same standards as 
the  project  road,  while  the  road  from  Erdene  and  Orgon  will  be  single-lane  roads  with  double 
bituminous  surface  treatment  (DBST)  surface,  with  4  m  wide  pavement,  and  1  m  shoulders.  
The amount of $3.6 million equivalent will be allocated for constructing the access roads. 
 
25. 
Roadside  Stations.  Roadside  stations  serve  as  a  place  for  interaction  between  road 
operators/users and local communities, and offer an organized venue for local specialty shops, 
restaurants,  rests,  emergency  services,  gas  stations,  and  centers  for  traffic  and  local 
information, thus stimulating local business, jobs, and revenues. Roadside stations also reduce 
the  transport  costs  of  local  residents  to  distant  markets.  A  pilot  roadside  station  at  the 
intersection between the project road and the access road linking Erdene is proposed for grant 
funding from the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR).24 Erdene was selected for its high 
poverty  incidence,  underdeveloped  status,  availability  of  resources,  and  reasonable  intervals 
between aimag centers.25 The pilot roadside station will be developed  with the participation of 
local  communities.  The  proposed  JFPR  grant  is  expected  to  finance  detailed  design  of  the 
roadside  station,  skills  training  for  small  enterprise  development  and  the  poor,  and  the 
establishment  and  operation  of  a  community-based  participatory  monitoring  and  evaluation 
system. If the pilot roadside station is successful, the Government plans to replicate it in other 
road sector projects. 
 
Local  Laborers’  Training  on  Road  Construction  and  Maintenance.  Training  for 
26. 
semiskilled equipment operators and construction workers will be conducted in the project area 
within  12  months  after  loan  effectiveness  to  ensure  maximum  use  of  local  labor  during  road 
construction.  DOR  will  conduct  the  training  program,  while  the  governments  of  Dornogovi  and 
Govisumber  aimags  will  select  the  trainees,  preferably  unemployed  youths.  The  trainees  are 
expected  to  be  hired  first  for  constructing  access  roads.  With  the  experience  gained,  they  will 
likely be hired for constructing the project road. DOR will also train households living along the 
project road on road maintenance 1 year before project completion. These households will then 
be contracted by DOR to maintain short segments of the project road. The amount of $63,000 
equivalent will be allocated for the training program. 
 
27. 
Stakeholder  Participation.  Stakeholder  participation  began  during  project  preparation 
and  will  continue  during  implementation  to  enhance  the  local  community’s  ownership  of  the 
Project. Stakeholder participation will focus on (i) support for maximum use of local labor during 
road construction and for good working conditions, (ii) job creation through business advice and 
skills development, (iii) development of roadside stations, (iv) implementation of the road safety 
program, (iv) involvement of households in road maintenance, (v) awareness and prevention of 
HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking,  and  (vi)  community-based  environmental  enhancement  and 
monitoring. A local nongovernment organization (NGO) will be engaged to facilitate stakeholder 
participation. The amount of $128,800 equivalent will be allocated for the service.

5. 

Awareness and Prevention of HIV/AIDS and Human Trafficking 

28.  While  Mongolia  is  at  the  early  stage  of  HIV/AIDS  epidemics  with  only  four  registered 
cases,26  the  country  is  vulnerable  to  diseases  due  to  high-risk  behavior  among  the  young 
population,  an  increasing  number  of  sex  workers  inexperienced  on  condom  use,  high 
prevalence of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), and rapidly growing HIV/AIDS diseases in 
the neighboring countries. The construction of the project road and the operation of the north-
south road transport corridor after project completion may increase the spread of HIV/AIDS and 
human  trafficking  because  of  a  large  number  of  workers  during  construction  and  increased 
movement  of  the  population  across  the  borders  with  the  PRC  and  Russia.  With  high  poverty 
incidence,  women  are  disproportionately  vulnerable 
for 
prostitution.27  The  TA  will  help  mitigate  potential  risks  of  HIV/AIDS  transmission  and  human 
trafficking along the north-south road corridor. 
 
C. 

to  HIV/AIDS  and 

Special Features 

trafficking 

Regional Cooperation. The Project will establish Mongolia’s first paved road corridor to 
29. 
link the Asian highway network of the PRC and Russia, and will strengthen Mongolia’s transport 
links to its trading partners in the region. The project road will serve as an important corridor for 
transit  traffic,  facilitating  trade  and  reducing  transaction  costs  in  the  region.  The  Republic  of 
Korea and the PRC will provide concessional or grant resources to cofinance the construction of 
the  project  road,  while  Japan  through  JFPR  is  expected  to  provide  financial  support  for 
establishing the pilot roadside station. Implementing the cross-border road transport facilitation 
plan  will  foster  the  efficient  movement  of  goods  and  passengers  between  Mongolia  and  the 
PRC. The Project is thus an example of ADB’s efforts in promoting regional cooperation. 
 
30. 
Policy  Dialogue.  ADB  has  continued  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  on  road 
sector financing (including the millennium road) and maintenance during the preparation of the 
Project.  Important  progress  has  been  made  in  this  regard.  Following  a  substantial  increase  in 
road  maintenance  funding  from  the  Road  Fund  to  MNT5.0  billion  ($4.2  million)  in  2004,28  the 
Government  agreed  to  continue  to  increase  road  maintenance  funding  by  8%  per  annum  to 
MNT7.5  billion  in  2009  to  fully  meet  the  funding  requirement.  Moreover,  the  Project  includes 
establishing a facility in Zamyn-Uud to collect vehicle fees beginning in 2009, with fee revenues 
to  be  allocated  to  the  Road  Fund  for  road  maintenance.29  Based  on  projected  traffic,  the 
estimated fee revenues would amount to about $2.0 million in 2009 and would increase to $3.6 
million  in  2025  (Appendix  5).30  This  amount  will  not  only  be  sufficient  to  cover  the  estimated 
annual  maintenance  cost  of  $1.9  million  for  the  project  road,  but  also  contribute  to  funding  to 
maintain other priority roads in the country. The Government has agreed to engage the private 
sector for the fee collection services. These measures will complement the development of the 
Government’s new transport sector strategy to address road sector financing and maintenance 
issues over the medium term. 
 
31. 
Impact  on  Local  Communities.  The  Project  has  been  formulated  to  maximize  the 
poverty  reduction  impact  on  local  communities  through  the  area  development  component.

The  construction  of  local  roads  will  improve  the  access  of  local  residents  to  markets,  job 
opportunities,  and  social  services.  The  establishment  of  the  pilot  roadside  station  will  expand 
local business and create jobs for local people. Training on road construction and maintenance 
will  improve  the  skills  of  local  laborers,  including  the  poor,  so  that  they  could  be  hired  during 
project  implementation.  The  stakeholder  participatory  process  will  encourage  involvement  of 
local  communities  in  project  design  and  implementation.  With  these  activities,  the  Project  will 
contribute to economic growth and poverty reduction in the project area. 
 
Awareness  and  Prevention  of  HIV/AIDS  and  Human  Trafficking.  The  Project 
32. 
includes the TA to address the risks of HIV/AIDS transmission and human trafficking, which may 
be  associated  with  a  large  number  of  construction  workers  and  the  increased  cross-border 
movement of the population along the north-south road corridor after project completion. This is 
the  first  externally  financed  project  in  Mongolia  that  will  help  develop  road  infrastructure  and 
address  the  issues  of  HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking  concurrently.  This  combination  will 
strengthen the positive social impacts of the Project. 
 
Stakeholder Participation and Consultation. During project preparation, consultations 
33. 
were held with the Government, civil society, local communities, and other external aid agencies 
on major issues such as project alternatives, route alignment, social and environmental impacts, 
and  project  benefits  for  local  communities  (Appendix  6).  The  consultations  revealed  a  high 
degree of public support for the Project. Stakeholder participation and consultation will continue 
during project implementation under the area development component.  
 
D. 

Cost Estimates

E. 

Financing Plan 

35. 
The Government has requested ADB to provide a loan in various currencies equivalent 
to SDR25,505,000 ($37.13 million equivalent) from its Special Funds resources to help finance 
the Project. The proposed loan will finance $31.6 million (59.8%) of the foreign exchange cost 
and $5.5 million equivalent (21.7%) of the local currency cost, or 47.5% of the total project cost. 
The  Republic  of  Korea  and  the  PRC  will  cofinance  the  Project  on  a  parallel  basis.  
The  Government  of  the  Republic  of  Korea  will  extend  a  loan  of  $23.9  million  equivalent  on 
concessional terms to finance 30.6% of the total project cost for civil works for part of the Choyr-
Saynshand  section.  The  PRC  Government  will  provide  a  grant  of  $1.5  million  equivalent  to 
finance 1.9% of the total project cost for civil works for upgrading the section between Zamyn-
Uud  and  the  border  with  the  PRC.  The  Mongolian  Government  will  finance  20%  of  the  total 
project cost (i.e., $15.6 million equivalent) including local taxes and duties. 
 
36. 
The proposed ADB loan will have a term of 32 years including a grace period of 8 years, 
with  an  interest  charge  at  the  rate  of  1.0%  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per 
annum thereafter. The loan from the Republic of Korea will have a maturity of 30 years including 
a  grace  period  of  10  years,  with  an  interest  rate  of  2%  per  annum.  The  Borrower  will  be 
Mongolia. A proposed financing plan is summarized in Table 2.

up  at  the  central  level  to  supervise  project  implementation.  It  will  be  chaired  by  the  state

environment, DOR, and governments of Dornogovi and Govisumber aimags. The PSC will meet 
at least once every 6 months to review the progress of implementation and provide guidance, as 
necessary. ADB will attend the PSC meetings as observer.

funded by the loan from the Republic of Korea and the other to implement the remaining project

by  consulting  firms  with  experience  in  detailed  design  and  implementation  of  road  projects  of 
similar nature and size. The supervision team will be mobilized on the date the contractor begin 
the  works.  During  the  defect  liability  period,  the  resident  engineer  will  continue  on  a  part-time

basis.

5. 

Disbursement Arrangements 

46. 
The  proposed  ADB  loan  will  be  disbursed  according  to  ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement 
Handbook  (January  2001).  Since  most  payments  will  be  made  for  contracts  well  above 
$100,000,  direct  payment  procedures  will  be  used  to  withdraw  the  loan  funds.  If  government 
funds are first used for eligible expenditures, ADB's reimbursement procedures will be applied. 
To  expedite  loan  disbursement,  the  Government  will  open  after  loan  effectiveness  an  imprest 
account at a commercial bank acceptable to ADB, with an initial deposit of $500,000 equivalent. 
The  imprest  account  will  be  managed  and  liquidated  according  to  ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement 
Handbook and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB. ADB’s statement of expenditures (SOE) 
procedure  may  be  used  for  reimbursing  eligible  expenses  and  liquidating  advances  from  the 
imprest  account.  Any  individual  payment  to  be  reimbursed  or  liquidated  under  the  SOE 
procedure will not exceed $100,000 equivalent. 
 
47. 
To  ensure  smooth  project  implementation,  the  proposed  ADB  loan,  the  loan  from  the 
Republic of Korea, the PRC grant, and counterpart funding from the Mongolian Government are 
required to be disbursed according to the implementation schedule in Appendix 8.

7. 

Project Performance Monitoring and Evaluation 

50. 
The  Mission  and  the  Government  have  jointly  prepared  a  project  performance 
monitoring system (PPMS) (Appendix 10). The baseline values for project impact indicators will 
be  established  before  project  implementation.  Monitoring  indicators  will  be  measured  with  the 
necessary  frequency  during  project  implementation.  Findings  will  be  incorporated  in  quarterly 
reports  to  ADB.  In  addition  to  indicators  for  implementation  monitoring,  indicators  for  project 
evaluation will be measured at project completion and 3 years after completion. Where relevant, 
indicators  will  be  disaggregated  by  sex.  Participatory  surveys  will  be  conducted  and  results 
compared with the baseline values. The construction supervision consultant will assist DOR in 
monitoring  and  evaluating  the  economic,  social,  and  environmental  impacts  of  the  Project.  
At inception, project completion, and 3 years after completion, DOR will submit to ADB a report 
that summarizes the key findings of monitoring and evaluation of changes that occurred in the  
3 preceding years. 
 

8. 

Project Review 

51. 
ADB will conduct regular (at least once a year) reviews of the Project‘s progress. If the 
reviews  show  serious  implementation  problems,  the  Government  and  ADB  will  agree  on 
appropriate mitigating measures to ensure achievement of the project objectives. In the second 
year  of  construction  of  the  project  road,  the  Government  and  ADB  will  carry  out  a  midterm 
review of the Project to assess (i) implementation status; (ii) design and construction standards; 
(iii) performance of consultants and contractors; (iv) project impacts, particularly those relating 
to  institutional,  administrative,  technical,  economic,  environmental,  and  social  aspects  and 
poverty  reduction;  (v)  progress  on  road  sector  reforms;  (vi)  status  of  compliance  with  the 
covenants stipulated in the loan agreement; and (vii) the need for additional works or changes in 
project  scope.  With  assistance  from  DOR,  ADB  will  make  a  preliminary  assessment  of  the 
socioeconomic impacts of the Project by comparing indicators collected at the midterm review 
with the baseline data. 
 

9. 

Anticorruption 

52. 
The Mission emphasized ADB’s anticorruption policy to the Government and executing 
agency, highlighting the section on fraud and corruption in ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
The Mission also assessed financial management and procurement capacity in Mongolia. DOR 
has adopted accounting and auditing procedures according to the Law on Accounting (approved 
in  2002)  and  the  State  Audit  Law  (approved  in  2003),  which  are  based  on  international 
accounting  and  auditing  standards.  Mongolia’s  performance  in  submitting  audited  project 
accounts  and  financial  statements  for  ADB-assisted  projects  has  been  generally  satisfactory, 
although there was one case of noncompliance each year during 2001−2003. The risks of theft 
or misappropriation of ADB funds are comparatively low in Mongolia, but the country needs to 
continue  anticorruption  efforts.  The  Government  has  agreed  to  follow  ADB’s  anticorruption 
policy during project implementation.

IV. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

53. 
The Government has requested ADB to provide under the Project TA for awareness and 
prevention of HIV/AIDS and human trafficking on the north-south road corridor. The goal of the 
TA  is  to  reduce  the  risks  of  HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking  that  may  be  associated  with  the 
construction  of  the  project  road  and  operation  of  the  north-south  road  transport  corridor  after 
project completion. The purposes of the TA are to (i) raise public awareness of HIV/AIDS and 
human  trafficking;  (ii)  address  the  risk  of  HIV/AIDS  transmission  among  construction  workers, 
sex workers, local communities, truck drivers, and other road users; and (iii) strengthen border 
control capacity against human trafficking. Consultants with expertise in anti-human trafficking, 
health  education  and  advocacy,  HIV/AIDS  medical  services,  and  epidemiological  surveillance 
and monitoring will provide 1.5 (international) and 160 (domestic) person-months of consulting 
services.  Individual  consultants  will  be  recruited  according  to  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  selecting  and  engaging  domestic 
consultants. Equipment, supplies, and materials will be procured following ADB’s Guidelines for 
Procurement. Outline terms of reference for the TA consultants are in Appendix 11. 
 
54. 
The  TA  cost  is  estimated  at  $420,000  equivalent,  comprising  $115,000  in  foreign 
exchange  and  $305,000  equivalent  in  local  currency.  A  grant  of  $350,000  equivalent  from 
ADB’s TA funding program is proposed to cover the entire foreign exchange cost and $235,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost. The Government will finance the remaining local currency 
cost by providing counterpart staff, office space, and workshop facilities.  
 
55. 
The  Ministry  of  Health  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  and  will  implement  the  TA  in 
coordination  with  DOR.  The  PIU  of  the  ADB-assisted  Second  Health  Sector  Development 
Project32  (Loan  1998)  will  be  the  Implementing  Agency.  A  full-time  TA  coordinator  will  be 
appointed  and  two  small  offices  with  part-time  assistants  will  be  set  up  at  the  health 
departments  of  Dornogovi  and  Govisumber  aimags  in  Saynshand  and  Choyr,  respectively.  
A  steering  committee  will  be  established  at  the  national  level  to  guide  TA  implementation.  
The  steering  committee  will  be  chaired  by  a  vice  minister  of  health  and  comprise 
representatives of the PIU of the Second Health Sector Development Project, DOR, ministries 
of  health  and  justice  and  home  affairs,  the  General  Customs  Office,  and  a  technical  expert 
group. Advisory groups will also be set up at local levels, chaired by the governors’ offices, with 
representatives of aimag health and road departments; local transport operators; police, border, 
and customs officers; local communities; and relevant NGOs. The TA will be implemented over 
4.5 years, from February 2005 to July 2009. 
 

V. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Project Benefits 

56. 
The  Project  will  benefit  the  people  living  along  the  road  corridor  in  Mongolia  (about 
48,400  based  on  the  2003  population),  road  transport  operators  and  users,  construction 
companies,  traders,  and  other  people  who  derive  income  from  expanded  traffic,  trade,  and 
investment  in  the  region.  The  major  benefits  would  accrue  in  the  form  of  improved  trade  and 
transit, and the significant reduction in transaction costs among the PRC, Mongolia, Russia, and 
other  trading  partners.  Major  direct  benefits  will  be  lower  transport  costs,  faster  and  more 
reliable  road  transport  services,  and  job  and  income  opportunities  created  during  project

Mongolia for the Second Health Sector Development Project. Manila. 

 16

 

 

implementation  (i.e.,  use  of  local  labor  and  construction  materials)  or  after  project  completion. 
The Project is expected to create about 1,800 jobs on road construction for Mongolians, which 
will generate income amounting to MNT3.4 billion ($2.9 million). Moreover, 210 households are 
expected to be hired to maintain the project road, which will provide an average supplemental 
income  of  MNT55,000  ($48)  per  family  per  year.  Improved  access  to  markets  and  reduced 
transport costs will also help reduce prices and improve the quality and availability of food and 
other traded goods. Indirect benefits will be increased business and job opportunities that have 
backward or forward linkages to the Project in Mongolia, the PRC, and Russia.  
 
57. 
Distribution  analysis  shows  that  the  Project  will  result  in  net  benefits  of  $268.3  million, 
comprising $235.7 million for Mongolia, $29.4 million for the PRC, and $3.2 million for Russia. 
Mongolia will account for 87.8% of the total benefits, while the PRC and Russia are expected to 
receive  11%  and  1.2%  of  the  total  benefits,  respectively.  Within  Mongolia,  passengers  and 
freight shippers are the major beneficiaries, accounting for 57.8% and 26.3% of total benefits. 
The Government’s share is 15.9%. 
 
B. 

Economic Analysis 

The  economic  analysis33  of  the  Project  compared  the  with-  and  without-project  cases 
58. 
(Appendix  12).  The  analysis  is  based  on  2003  economic  prices  and  covers  20  years 
(2006−2025) comprising 3 years of construction and 17 years of operation. 
 
59. 
Traffic  forecasts  for  2006−2025  were  made  based  on  an  analysis  of  macro  level 
demographic and economic trends for Mongolia as well as for the corridor between Choyr and 
the PRC border in Zamyn-Uud, and traffic surveys conducted along the project road. Mongolia’s 
GDP  is  projected  to  grow  by  4.5%  per  annum  and  its  population  to  increase  by  0.95%  per 
annum during 2006−2025; these figures are largely in line with recent growth rates. Based on 
economic and demographic growth projections, aggregate traffic for the corridor between Choyr 
and  the  PRC  border  in  Zamyn-Uud  is  forecast  to  grow  by  6.3%  for  freight  traffic  in  TKM  and 
5.1%  for  passenger  traffic  in  PKM  during  2006−2025.  Traffic  growth  rates  are  higher  than  the 
rate  for  GDP  because  transport  intensity  of  the  economy  has  increased  in  recent  years,  with 
freight transport intensity growing at a faster rate than passenger transport intensity. 
 
60. 
Transport  between  Choyr  and  Zamyn-Uud  is  by  road  and  rail.  Based  on  the  existing 
modal  shares  and  an  analysis  of  traffic  patterns  on  modal  preference  derived  from  traffic 
surveys, the projected corridor traffic was disaggregated into road and rail modes. The railway is 
projected to remain the dominant mode of transport, although its shares in TKM and PKM are 
expected to decrease gradually. The road will attract traffic, particularly from 2009 mainly due to 
diverted traffic from railways. The share of the road is projected to increase from 0.4% to 5.8% 
in TKM and from 3.7% to 23.8% in PKM during 2006–2025. 
 
61. 
On  the  basis  of  projected  corridor  traffic,  traffic  count  surveys  along  the  project  road 
alignment  during  August−September  2003,  and  data  from  DOR,  traffic  forecasts  for  with-  and 
without-project  cases  were  made.  In  the  without-project  case,  traffic  would  continue  to  move 
along  the  existing  multiple  unimproved  earth  tracks  (normal  traffic).  The  average  daily  traffic 
(ADT) will remain relatively low, from 288 vehicles in 2006 to 864 vehicles in 2025. In the with- 
project case, ADT will increase significantly from 2009, the first year of operation of the project 

                                                 
33 The  economic  analysis  covers  Mongolia  only  and  does  not  take  into  account  the  project  benefits  accruing  to  the 

PRC and Russia. 

 

 

  

 

 17

road, since the road is forecast to carry diverted and generated traffic. ADT is projected to grow 
from  288  vehicles  in  2006  to  3,075  vehicles  in  2025.  Regional  traffic  (i.e.,  traffic  from  or  to 
Mongolia  and  transit  traffic  via  Mongolia)  is  projected  to  constitute  the  majority  of  total  traffic, 
with its share growing from about 30% in 2006 to 75% in 2025. 
 
62. 
There  are  four  ways  of  meeting  the  projected  road  traffic  between  Choyr  and  Zamyn-
Uud: (i) construction of an asphalt concrete road; (ii) construction of a road with DBST surface; 
(iii)  construction  of  a  gravel  road;  and  (iv)  expansion  of  the  capacity  of  the  existing  railway 
instead of constructing the project road, given that the preliminary alignment for the project road 
roughly parallels the railway line. An alternatives analysis shows that the railway alternative has 
the  lowest  value  in  terms  of  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  (19.7%)  and  net  present 
value (NPV, $59.1 million), and is thus less economically feasible. The gravel road option has 
the second lowest value, with an EIRR of 26.4% and NPV of $68.2 million. The EIRR is highest 
for the DBST road option (30.4%) and the second highest for the asphalt concrete road option 
(29.7%).  In  terms  of  NPV,  the  asphalt  concrete  road  option  ($131.3  million)  shows  a  higher 
value than the DBST road option ($121.9 million). In view of NPV and given that the project road 
forms  part  of  the  Asian  highway  network  and  other  sections  of  the  north-south  road  corridor 
between Altanbulag and Choyr are asphalt concrete, the asphalt concrete road option appears 
a  better  choice  than  the  DBST  option.  The  alternatives  analysis  indicated  that  an  asphalt 
concrete road between Choyr and the PRC border  in Zamyn-Uud is the economically efficient 
option for increasing transport capacity on this corridor.  
 
63. 
The Project’s primary benefit is transport cost savings due to the improved road surface 
roughness34 and resultant increases in vehicle speeds. Transport cost savings are estimated to 
account  for  96%  of  the  total  project  benefits.  The  Project  is  expected  to  result  in  an  average 
vehicle operating cost reduction of 43.1% per unit traveling between Choyr and the PRC border 
in Zamyn-Uud, ranging between 36.1% per car and 45.5% per heavy bus. The Project will also 
save  travel time  because  of  the  relatively  straight  alignment  of  the  project  road  and  increased 
average vehicle speeds. The Project is expected to reduce average travel time between Choyr 
and the PRC border in Zamyn-Uud by 56%, from 13.4 hours to 5.9 hours per trip. The Project 
will contribute to reducing road accidents, but such benefits are not quantifiable and thus are not 
included  in  the  economic  analysis.  The  Project  is  not  designed  to  alleviate  traffic  congestion 
since  congestion  is  generally  not  a  concern  in  the  road  sector  of  Mongolia,  except  for 
Ulaanbaatar during the rush hours on workdays. 
 
64. 
Sensitivity analysis shows that the EIRR of the Project exceeds the cutoff level of 12%, 
except  when  (i)  the  Project’s  capital  costs  increase  by  214%,  (ii)  road  maintenance  costs 
increase  by  1,139%,  (iii)  the  surface  roughness  of  the  project  road  during  the  dry  season 
increases by 175%, and (iv) traffic growth or user benefits are reduced by 66%. However, such 
significant changes in those variables are unlikely to occur. 
 
65. 
Risk analysis examined the probability distribution of the estimated EIRR and NPV of the 
Project. Within the assumed range of parameter estimates, the probability that the EIRR of the 
Project is less than 12% or NPV is negative 26%. The median EIRR is 14.7% with a range of 
0.5%−31.5%,  and  the  medium  NPV  amounts  to  $22.7  million  with  a  range  of  negative  $110.9 
million–$152.2 million. 
 

                                                 
34 The Project  will significantly improve the road surface roughness between Choyr and the border  with the PRC in 

Zamyn-Uud, with reduction in its international roughness index value from the present 20−22 to 2−3. 

 18

 

 

C. 

Project Impacts 

1. 

Impact on Poverty Reduction  

The  Project  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  in  Mongolia  by  creating  jobs  and 
66. 
promoting  sustainable  economic  growth.  The  social  and  poverty  analysis  undertaken  during 
project preparation shows that about 10,500 poor (or 21.6% of total project beneficiaries) in the 
project  area  will  benefit.  The  major  poverty  reduction  impacts  of  the  Project  will  include  
(i)  creating  jobs  and  income  for  the  poor  in  road  construction  and  maintenance,  and  the 
establishment of the pilot roadside station; (ii) building local roads to increase the access of poor 
communities  to  markets  and  social  services;  (iii)  developing  job  skills  of  the  poor  through 
training; (iv) lowering prices of food and other daily necessities in local markets due to reduced 
transport costs and travel time; (v) improving water supply from wells constructed during project 
implementation; (vi) improving road safety; and (vii) addressing potential risks of HIV/AIDS and 
human  trafficking.  For  the  poor,  the  Project  is  expected  to  create  about  770  jobs  in  road 
construction,  comprising  130  for  skilled  and  semiskilled  labor  and  640  for  unskilled  labor. 
Moreover, about 70 poor households will likely be hired to maintain the project road after project 
completion.  By  the  current  wage  level  in  Mongolia,  these  jobs  are  expected  to  earn  a  total 
annual  salary  of  $1.2  million  and  help  lift  1,574  poor  households  (about  6,300  people)  out  of 
poverty.  The  Project  will  thus  move  Mongolia  toward  achieving  the  Millennium  Development 
Goals.35 A summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 13. 
 

2. 

Social and Gender Impacts 

Land acquired for the Project and temporary use of land for construction will not involve 
67. 
any  removal  of  structures  or  affect  private  landowners.  The  land  acquired  for  the  project  road 
and access roads is state-owned, and is either wasteland or communal grazing land. The area 
of grazing land lost is insignificant compared with the total area required for grazing. There are 
adequate  government  regulations  and  procedures  for  transferring  the  right-of-way  to  DOR.  
The Project requires no resettlement. 
 
68. 
The  Project  will  not  adversely  affect  the  livelihoods  of  ethnic  minority  groups,  who 
include Kazakh, Durvud, and Bayad and account for 3.5% of the population in the project area. 
These  groups  do  not  face  discrimination  and  are  not  considered  vulnerable.  The  Project  will 
have no significant adverse impacts on the livelihoods of nomadic herders in the project area. 
Instead, it can help spur the development of the local livestock industry with improved access to 
markets and growing domestic and regional demands for livestock products. 
 
69. 
The vulnerable groups in the project area are the poor, women (especially single female 
heads  of  households,  or  those  with  disabled  family  members),  the  disabled  or  chronically  ill, 
orphans, the elderly, and unemployed youths. The major constraint for these groups is the lack 
of  job  opportunities  and  skills.  The  Project  will  provide  equal  job  opportunities  for  women  and 
other vulnerable groups, help develop their skills, and address their needs by engaging them in 
project  design  and  implementation.  Measures  to  promote  women's  participation  and  mitigate 
potentially  negative  impacts  on  women  are  integrated  into  the  project  components  and 
assurances. 
 

                                                 
35 ADB’s Country Strategy and Program Update for Mongolia (2004−2006) (footnote 19) states: “To help the country 
achieve  the  Millennium  Development  Goals,  ADB  needs  to  continue  to  help  promote  economic  growth  for  job 
creation and improve provision of essential social services for the poor.”  

 

  

 

 19

The  Project  will  also  have  positive  social  impacts  with  the  implementation  of  specific 
70. 
components  or  measures  to  address  issues  such  as  HIV/AIDS,  human  trafficking,  adequate 
working conditions, and road safety. 
 

3. 

Environmental Impact  

71. 
ADB  classifies  the  Project  in  environmental  category  “B  sensitive”.  The  environmental 
impact  assessment  (EIA)  was  undertaken  through  broad-based  public  consultations,  and  the 
summary was circulated to the Board and made public on the ADB web site on 5 March 2004. 
The EIA approved by the Ministry of Nature and Environment on 12 May 2004 concludes that 
the Project will have no major adverse impacts on the environment. The project road alignment, 
which follows the railway line and crosses steppe and semidesert areas, does not impinge on 
any  existing  or  planned  protected  areas  and  is  not  expected  to  affect  wildlife  migration. 
Operation of a paved road will improve the environment as it provides an alternative to currently 
driving  through  multiple  unimproved  earth  tracks,  which  has  contributed  to  land  degradation. 
Planting  of  vegetation  at  specific  locations  along  the  project  road  will  help  improve  the 
environment by controlling snow and sand drifts. The Government will implement the mitigating 
measures proposed in the EIA during project implementation. 
 
D. 

Project Risks 

72. 
The  Project  has  three  potential  risks.  First,  there  might  be  implementation  delays 
because  of  DOR’s  limited  experience  in  managing  the  construction  of  a  relatively  long  road. 
This  risk  will  be  mitigated  by  consulting  services  to  assist  in  project  management  and 
implementation,  and  advance  action  on  procurement.  Second,  counterpart  funds  may  not  be 
provided on a timely basis. ADB will work closely with the Government to ensure that sufficient 
counterpart  funds  for  the  Project  are  allocated  in  a  timely  manner.  Third,  maintenance  of  the 
project  road  after  completion  may  be  inadequate  due  to  insufficient  funding.  This  risk  will  be 
mitigated  mainly  through  the  establishment  of  the  facility  in  Zamyn-Uud  to  collect vehicle  fees 
beginning in 2009, with fee revenues allocated to the Road Fund for maintenance of the project 
road. The fee revenues will be sufficient to cover the estimated annual maintenance cost of the 
project road to ensure sustainability. 
 

VI. 

ASSURANCES 

A. 

Specific Assurances 

In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 

Project Funding. The Government will ensure that all counterpart funds required for the 

73. 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents: 
 
74. 
Project are provided on a timely basis. 
 
75. 
Project Monitoring and Evaluation. DOR will ensure that (i) baseline values for project 
impact indicators are established before project implementation; (ii) findings on these indicators 
during  project  implementation  are  incorporated  in  quarterly  reports  submitted  to  ADB;  and  
(iii)  project  impacts  are  monitored  and  evaluated  through  surveys  at  project  completion  and  
3 years after completion, and findings are reported to ADB. 
 
76. 
Road Maintenance. The Government will ensure that (i) road maintenance funding from 
the Road Fund is increased by at least 8% per annum from MNT5.0 billion in 2004 to MNT7.5 

 20

 

 

billion in 2009; (ii) a facility is established in Zamyn-Uud to collect vehicle fees beginning in 2009 
with  fee  revenues  to  be  allocated  to  the  Road  Fund,  first  for  maintaining  the  project  road  and 
then  for  other  priority  roads  in  the  country;  and  (iii)  DOR  engages  a  private  firm  for  managing 
the operation of the fee collection facility. DOR will ensure that road maintenance units are set 
up  in  Ayrag,  Choyr,  Erdene,  and  Zamyn-Uud,  and  the  state-owned  maintenance  company  in 
Saynshand  is  provided  with  additional  staff  and  equipment  before  the  project  road  opens.  
The  Government  will  have  actual  expenses  on  road  maintenance  audited  annually  by 
independent auditors according to international auditing standards, and will furnish ADB with an 
audit report to ADB within 6 months of the end of each fiscal year. 
 
77. 
Cross-Border Road Transport Facilitation Plan. The Government will ensure that (i) it 
approves the cross-border road transport facilitation plan (Appendix 4) by 30 September 2004, 
and (ii) all actions in the plan are undertaken according to the schedule. 
 
78. 
Vehicle Weight Control. The Government will ensure that vehicle axle weight limits are 
established  and  enforced  to  prevent  overloaded  vehicles  from  entering  the  project  road 
beginning in 2006. 
 
79. 
Road  Safety.  DOR  will  ensure  that  (i)  detailed  project  design  includes  road  safety 
features,  and  (ii)  independent  road  safety  audit  of  the  detailed  design  of  the  project  road  is 
conducted  before  civil  works  begin.  DOR  will  notify  TPD  12  months  and  6  months  before  the 
completion of the project road, so that TPD can plan a traffic safety awareness and enforcement 
campaign. DOR will procure patrol vehicles and communication equipment in coordination with 
TPD,  and  TPD  will  ensure  proper  maintenance  of  patrol  vehicles  and  the  communication 
equipment. 
 
80. 
Environment.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  (i)  the  Project  is  implemented  and 
project  facilities  are  operated  and  maintained  according  to  existing  laws  and  government 
regulations  and  standards  concerning  environmental  protection,  and  ADB’s  environmental 
guidelines; (ii) the guidelines developed under the EIA and the summary EIA are incorporated 
into  the  design,  construction,  and  operation  of  project  facilities;  (iii)  environmental  mitigating 
measures  and  monitoring  requirements  identified  in  the  EIA  and  the  summary  EIA  are  fully 
implemented during project implementation; and (iv) all necessary environmental approvals and 
clearances,  as  required  under  relevant  laws  and  government  regulations,  are  obtained  in  a 
timely manner. 
 
Resettlement.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  the  Project  does  not  entail  any  land 
81. 
acquisition and resettlement. In the event of any unforeseen resettlement, the Government will 
inform  ADB  and  prepare  a  resettlement  plan  according  to  relevant  laws  and  regulations,  and 
ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and Handbook on Resettlement. Construction of civil 
works will not start until ADB has reviewed and approved the resettlement plan. 
 
82. 
Indigenous  People.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  the  Project  does  not  have  any 
adverse  impact  on  the  livelihood  of  nomadic  herders  and  ethnic  minority  groups  living  in  the 
project area.  
 
83. 
Health Risks and Human Trafficking. The Government will ensure that (i) contractors 
disseminate  information  on  the  risks  of  HIV/AIDS/STIs  and  human  trafficking  to  workers 
employed  during  project  implementation;  (ii)  similar  information  is  disseminated  to  local 
communities  in  the  project  area,  road  transport  operators,  and  road  users  during  operation  of 

 

  

 

 21

the project facilities; and (iii) contractors allow the HIV/AIDS teams to  conduct workshops and 
give workers time to be tested or receive treatment.  
 
84. 
Labor. DOR will verify that the Professional Inspectorate monitors the contractors’ hiring 
and equal pay practices as well as wourking conditions, and will encourage women and other 
vulnerable  groups  to  participate  in  project  design  and  implementation.  DOR  will  clearly  state 
wage, worker safety, and work camp living standard requirements in the tender documents and 
contracts according to relevant laws and government regulations, and will monitor the effects on 
women and other vulnerable groups during project implementation. 
 
B. 

Condition for Loan Disbursement 

Before  the  disbursement  of  the  proposed  ADB  loan  for  civil  works,  the  agreements 
85. 
covering  the  loan  from  the  Republic  of  Korea  and  the  grant  from  the  PRC,  in  form  and 
substance  satisfactory  to  ADB,  will  have  been  signed  and  have  become  effective;  or  the 
Government will have made alternative funding arrangements acceptable to ADB. 
 

VII. 

RECOMMENDATION 

86. 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  loan  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of 
ADB  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to 
Special  Drawing  Rights  25,505,000  to  Mongolia  for  the  Regional  Road  Development  Project 
from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  with  an  interest  charge  at  the  rate  of  1.0%  per  annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; a term of 32 years, including a grace 
period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft Loan Agreement presented to the Board.

ROAD SECTOR ANALYSIS 

Transport Modes 

A. 
 
1. 
Mongolia’s  transport  sector  comprises  railways,  roads,  air  transport,  and  inland 
waterways. Railways are the dominant mode of transport, accounting for 97% of freight in ton-
kilometers (TKM) and about 55% of passengers in passenger-kilometers (PKM). Road transport 
carries  most  of  the  remaining  traffic,  accounting  for  about  3%  of  freight  in  TKM  and  20%  of 
passengers  in  PKM.  Air  transport  is  limited  by  poor  quality,  few  operational  airports,  and  high 
cost,  but  it  plays  a  key  role  in  providing  international  access  and  linking  the  otherwise 
inaccessible  aimag  (province)  centers.  The  role  of  inland  waterways  is  limited  to  a  few  lakes 
(e.g., Lake Khovsgol) located mainly in the northern part of the country. 
 
2. 
The large share of railways is due to neither the relatively large geographic area, nor a 
well-developed railway network in Mongolia. The railway network extends only 1,920 kilometers 
(km), primarily connecting Suhbaatar at the border with Russia to Zamyn-Uud at the border with 
the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC).  Mongolia’s  rail  line  density  is  1.2  km  per  km2,  lowest 
among  the  transition  economies  of  Eastern  Europe  and  the  Commonwealth  of  Independent 
Sates. Compared with Mongolia, other transition economies have higher rail line densities, but 
lower share of rail transport.1 It appears that the higher share of railways in Mongolia is primarily 
due to underdevelopment of its road network, which does not allow for efficient and competitive 
road transport (para. 4). 
 
Despite its relatively low share, road transport has the potential for rapid growth to meet 
3. 
the  needs  of  a  reviving  economy.  As  Mongolia  moves  toward  a  free  market  system  and 
transport  demand  becomes  more  diversified,  the  need  for  transport  services  with  a  greater 
degree of reliability, flexibility, and efficiency will increase significantly. Road transport is better 
placed than other transport modes to meet these demands. 
 
B. 
 

The Road Sector 

1. 

Road Network 

 
4. 
Mongolia has a road network of about 49,250 km, connecting 21 major cities and towns 
as well as 160 smaller villages. The network comprises (i) 11,063 km of about 30 state roads 
that connect Ulaanbaatar with aimag centers, major towns and border crossings; and (ii) 38,187 
km of local roads that link aimag centers with smaller villages. Only 12% of the roads (1,670 km) 
are  paved,  13%  (1,800  km)  are  gravel,  and  the  remaining  roads  are  earth  tracks.  Mongolia’s 
road network lags far behind that of other countries, including its neighbors. Road density (0.03 
km per km2) and the share of paved roads (3.4%) in Mongolia are both close to the lower end of 
the  countries  in  the  world.2  Moreover,  most  of  the  road  network  is  deteriorating  and  a  large 
proportion  remains  impassable  during  the  rainy  or  winter  seasons  due  to  inadequate 
maintenance. 
 
 

                                                 
1  For  example,  Kazakhstan  has  a  rail  line  density  of  5  km  per  km2,  but  its  railways  account  for  94%  of  freight 

transport in terms of TKM. 

2  The mid range values of road density and the share of paved roads in the world are 0.2 km per km2 and 45.5%,

Appendix 2 

2. 

Vehicle Ownership 

 
5. 
Mongolia’s  registered  vehicles  (private  vehicles  in  particular)  have  increased  rapidly 
since the mid-1990s due to economic recovery and progress on the transition to a market-based 
system.  The  average  annual  growth  rate  was  5.7%  during  1994−2003  and  it  accelerated  to 
about 8% over the last 4 years. In 2003 Mongolia had 138,307 registered vehicles, comprising 
69,531 cars, 27,827 trucks, 26,361 motorcycles, 9,937 buses, and 4,651 trailers (Table A2.1). 
The country’s vehicle ratio was 45.5 vehicles (four and above wheels) per 1,000 persons, which 
was  close  to  the  mid-value  in  the world  (45.8 vehicles  per  1,000  persons).  The  rise  in  vehicle 
ownership,  which  is  projected  to  continue  in  the  foreseeable  future,  highlights  the  potential 
growth of road transport and requires improvement and expansion of the road network.
