3. 

Road Sector Institutions and Regulatory Framework 

Sources: Traffic Police Department and National Statistical Yearbook, 1999 and 2002. 
 
 
 
6. 
The Ministry of Infrastructure is responsible for overall transport planning, regulation, and 
coordination. Within the ministry, the Policy and Coordination Department of Roads, Transport, 
and Tourism formulates transport policy, monitors  its implementation, and liaises with external 
aid  agencies.  Implementation  of  road  policy  and  operations  is  undertaken  by  the  Road 
Transport  Agency  and  the  Department  of  Roads  (DOR).  While  the  Road  Transport  Agency  is 
responsible for implementing policies and programs related to road transport operations, DOR is 
responsible for construction, rehabilitation, and maintenance of state roads. DOR is led by the 
director general and comprises a technical committee and four divisions, with permanent staff of 
61,  of  whom  41  are  professional  and  20  technical  or  administrative.  In  addition,  50  temporary 
employees are assigned to externally financed projects. 
 
The National Transport Advisory Committee, set up in February 1998 and reorganized in 
7. 
March 1999 and May 2000, monitors implementation of road sector policies. The committee is 
chaired by the director general of the Policy and Coordination Department of Roads, Transport, 
and Tourism of the Ministry of Infrastructure and comprises representatives of DOR; the Road 
Transport  Agency;  the  State  infrastructure  Control  Agency;  Traffic  Police  Department;  Urban 
Transport Coordination Department, National Transport Association; Trade Union for Workers of 
Transport,  Communications,  and  Petroleum  Companies;  and  state-owned  road  construction 
enterprises. 
 
8. 
Mongolia’s road sector policy is based mainly on the Road and Road Transport Sector 
Policy Statement and two main pieces of legislation: the Road Act and the Road Transport Act, 
which were developed with Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance.3 The Road Act, which 
became  effective  on  1  February  1998,  includes  provisions  for  road  sector  organizations  and 
institutional  jurisdictions,  road  infrastructure  classification  and  technical  standards,  and  road 

                                                 
3  ADB. 1999. Technical Assistance to Mongolia for Policy Support in the Road Sector. Manila. 

 

 Appendix 2

27

financing. The Road Transport Act, which took effect on 1 July 1999, focuses on licensing and 
regulatory aspects of the road transport industry. 

4. 

Financial Management 

 
The  road  sector  is  financed  primarily  through  the  Road  Fund  that  was  established  in 
9. 
1991, controlled by the Ministry of Finance and Economy and administered by DOR. Resource 
allocation of the Road Fund is part of the Government’s budget process, and the Road Fund is 
financed  mainly  from  the  state  budget  and  road  user  taxes.  The  state  Road  Fund  revenues 
increased from MNT6.4 billion ($6.3 million) in 1999 to MNT19.8 billion ($17.6 million) in 2003, 
with  the  allocation  from  the  state  budget  and  road  user  taxes  accounting  for  about  70%  and 
30%,  respectively,  of  the  total.  The  state  Road  Fund  revenues  are  used  to  finance  road 
construction,  rehabilitation,  and  maintenance,  as  well  as  serve  as  counterpart  funds  for 
externally  assisted  road  projects.  During  1999−2003,  road  construction  and  rehabilitation 
(including counterpart funding for externally assisted projects) accounted for about 90% of total 
expenditures. While the share of road maintenance in total expenditures rose from 5.8% in 1999 
to 9.3% in 2003, expenses on equipment and research declined from 3.7% to 0.5% during the 
same period (Table A2.2). 
 
10. 
Despite the recent increases, total Road Fund revenues have been inadequate to meet 
road  sector  funding  requirements,  which,  ranged  from  45%  to  79%  of  the  amount  needed  by 
DOR.  According  to  a  World  Bank  study,4  Mongolia’s  road  sector  requires  a  minimum  annual 
funding for capital investment and maintenance equivalent to 2.4% of GDP during 1999−2014. 
However,  the  actual  funding  during  1999−2003  accounted  for  less  than  1%  of  GDP.  Fiscal 
deficits of the Government (3.6% of GDP in 2003) and a high external debt (103.7% of GDP in 
2003)  are  the  primary  factors  limiting  government  funding  for  the  road  sector.  The  lack  of  an 
updated  sector  strategy  also  exacerbates  the  problem  because  without  the  strategy  the 
Government is unable to allocate limited financial resources to priority projects on the basis of 
the  country’s  development  strategy  and  sound  technical  and  economic  analyses.  As  a  result, 
part  of  the  Road  Fund  revenues  has  been  used  for  unplanned  new  projects,  particularly 
construction of the millennium road. Moreover, despite increases in the retail price of gasoline 
and diesel, the fuel taxes have not been adjusted since 1995. Vehicle license fees have also not 
been  allocated  to  the  state  Road  Fund,  but  instead  have  been  appropriated  to  local 
governments for purposes not related to roads.

Appendix 2 

The  Administration  and  Finance  Division  of  DOR 

As  a  recommendation  developed  with  ADB  technical  assistance,  the  Government 
11. 
established a Road Board in October 2003 to monitor operations of the Road Fund. The Road 
Board  is  chaired  by  the  Scientific  Secretary  of  the  Transport  Institute  and  comprises 
representatives  of  Ministries  of  Finance  and  Economy,  Infrastructure;  DOR;  Traffic  Police 
Department; major road transport companies, and transport nongovernment organizations. 
 
12. 
financial 
management  of  road  sector  accounts,  including  preparing  the  budget  of  the  Road  Fund, 
monitoring,  and  accounting  of  its  revenues  and  expenditures  as  well  as  road  sector  projects 
implemented  by  DOR.  The  division  has  eight  staff  members.  With  ADB  technical  assistance 
(footnote  3),  DOR’s  financial  management  has  improved.  DOR  has  adopted  accounting  and 
auditing procedures according to the Law on Accounting (approved in 2002) and the State Audit 
Law  (approved  in  2003),  which  are  based  on  international  accounting  and  auditing  standards. 
DOR’s  performance  in  submitting  audited  project  accounts  and  financial  statements  for  ADB-
assisted  projects  has  been  satisfactory.  However,  DOR’s  financial  management  capacity  has 
been constrained due to inadequate provision of government budgets. Despite rapid increases 
in  road  investment  in  recent  years,  funding  allocated  from  the  state  budget  for  financial 
management in DOR remains the same. The result is shortage of staff in the Administration and 
Finance Division. 
 

is  responsible 

for 

5. 

Road Maintenance 

 
13. 
Road maintenance funding has been inadequate to cover the needs of the road network. 
Expenditures  on  road  maintenance  from  the  state  Road  Fund  increased  from  MNT370  million 
($0.4 million) in 1999 to MNT1.8 billion ($1.6 million) in 2003, but it accounted for about 25% of 
the amount requested by DOR and less than 0.2% of GDP, and was lower than in many other 
Asian countries.5 Road maintenance funding from the Road Fund in 2004 increased significantly 
by more than 170% to MNT5.0 billion ($4.2 million). While this represented progress made on 
improving  road  maintenance  funding,  continued  efforts  are  needed  to  fully  address  this  issue. 
Inadequate  funding  for  road  maintenance  will  not  prevent  further  deterioration  of  the  road 
network and remedy the accumulation of deferred maintenance. According to the Road Board, 
the present conditions of the road network reach at best about 60% of the required level. 
 
14. 
The  problem  of  inadequate  funding  for  road  maintenance  in  Mongolia  is  similar  to  that 
experienced  in  many  other  developing  countries.  Fiscal  constraints  have  made  it  increasingly 
difficult  for  the  Government  to  provide  adequate  funds  for  the  road  sector.  Within  the  road 
sector,  priority  is  usually  given  to  road  construction  and  rehabilitation  (including  counterpart 
funding  for  externally  assisted  projects).  Road  maintenance  should  be  excluded  from  the 
government budget process and be funded primarily  from  road charges (e.g., road user taxes 
and fees) set at levels reflecting the costs that vehicles impose on the road system. 
 
15. 
The  Government  recently  took  steps  to  increase  funding  for  road  maintenance. 
Following  the  substantial  rise  in  road  maintenance  funding  in  2004,  the  Government  plans  to 
further  increase  it  to  MNT5.5  billion  in  2005.  The  establishment  of  the  Road  Board  will  help 
improve  the  efficiency  of  Road  Fund  resources  allocated  for  road  maintenance.  The  Road 
Board recommended to the Ministry of Finance and Economy in April 2004 that the Road Fund 
be used primarily for road maintenance and that road maintenance funding be further increased. 
As  a  first  step  in  encouraging  a  private  road  maintenance  industry,  the  Government  has 
removed  route  maintenance  activities  from  state-owned  companies  or  joint  shareholding 
                                                 
5  For  example,  the  share  of  road  maintenance  expenditures  to  GDP  was  1%  in  the  PRC,  0.7%  in  Viet  Nam,  and 

0.5% in Kazakhstan in the early to mid-1990s (footnote 4). 

 

 Appendix 2

29

companies. With support from the Nordic Development Fund, the Government is formulating a 
road maintenance plan to provide a sustainable technical basis for the funds allocated for road 
maintenance.  In  addition,  road  maintenance  equipment  was  procured  with  funding  from  ADB 
and  the  World  Bank,  and  a  framework  for  the  management  and  operation  of  the  stock 
maintenance equipment was established with ADB assistance. 
 

6. 

Road Safety 

 
Road accidents have increased significantly since the mid-1990s, with the total number 
16. 
growing from 860 in 1995 to 5,553 in 2002 (Table A2.3). The number of fatalities rose slightly, 
but  the  number  of  injuries  doubled  during  1995−2002.  The  increase  in  road  accidents  in  the 
urban areas (particularly in Ulaanbaatar) was more rapid than in the rural areas. Road accidents 
in the urban areas rose by about 750% during this period, compared with a 250% increase in 
the rural areas. Road accident fatalities in the urban areas increased by 50%, while the number 
of  deaths  was  relatively  unchanged  in  the  rural  areas.  However,  road  accidents  in  the  rural 
areas  rose  significantly  in  2002,  accounting  for  two  thirds  of  the  total  fatalities  in  the  country. 
The main reasons were poor driving skills, high speeds, intoxicated driving, careless behavior of 
pedestrians, deficient road conditions, and technical problems with vehicles.

17.  While the number of road accidents increased, the severity of accidents has decreased. 
The fatality rate per 10,000 vehicles declined by 50% during 1995−2002. Deaths per accident 
decreased  from  0.34  to  0.06,  and  injuries  from  1.01  to  0.29  during  the  same  period. 
Nevertheless,  the  fatality  rate  for  2002  was  about  24  persons  per  10,000  vehicles,  which 
remained  higher  than  in  many  other  Asian  countries.6  With  the  present  rate  of  growth  in 
vehicles, there is the potential for more road accidents. 
 
18.  Mongolia approved the Law on Road Safety and became a member of the International 
Convention  on  Road  Signage  in  1996.  The  Road  Signage  Standards  were  updated  in  2003, 
traffic safety regulations are being updated, and the standards on road marking and lighting are 
under  review.  Road  safety  guidelines  were  developed  with  ADB  assistance.7  An  accident 
reporting system was revised and a vehicle inspection system developed and implemented with 
World  Bank  assistance.  Nevertheless,  road  safety  features  (e.g.,  markings,  signage,  and 
guardrails)  are  lacking  on  some  road  sections  including  the  Altanbulag-Ulaanbaatar  section. 
                                                 
6  For example, the road accident fatality rate in the PRC for 2001 was 17 persons per 10,000 vehicles. 
7  ADB. 1995. Regional Technical Assistance for Regional Initiatives in Road Safety. Manila. 

 

 

 30

 

Appendix 2 

Government Strategy and Priorities for the Road Sector 

Moreover,  enforcement  of  traffic  safety  regulations  is  weak  due  to  the  limited  capacity  of  the 
Traffic  Police  Department,  as  most  traffic  police  officers  have  received  neither  appropriate 
training  nor  adequate  equipment  (e.g.,  patrol  vehicles,  breath  analyzers,  speed  monitoring 
equipment, and communication radios). Strong efforts are needed to (i) install safety features on 
all  state  roads,  (ii)  promote  public  awareness  of  traffic  safety,  (iii)  strengthen  the  capacity  of 
traffic  police  officers  through  training,  and  (iv)  provide  the  Traffic  Police  Department  with 
equipment  such  as  patrol  vehicles  equipped  with  breath  analyzers  and  portable  speed 
monitoring  equipment,  and  two-way  communication  radios  to  enforce  the  implementation  of 
road traffic regulations. 
 
C. 
 
The  Government’s  road  sector  strategy  aims  to  improve  the  efficiency  of  the  road 
19. 
transport  system  and  services  to  facilitate  the  country’s  economic  and  social  development.  
The  strategy  focuses  on  (i)  creating  a  favorable  environment  needed  for  developing  a 
competitive  road  transport  industry,  (ii)  increasing  investment  on  road  construction  and 
rehabilitation to reduce Mongolia’s isolation from world markets and improve the accessibility of 
isolated  communities  within  the  country,  (iii)  increasing  funding  for  road  maintenance,  
(iv) improving the efficiency of state-owned transport enterprises, and (v) improving road safety. 
 
20.  While  important  progress  has  been  made  on  creating  a  favorable  climate  for  a 
competitive road transport industry, severe budgetary constraints have limited the progress on 
increasing  funding  for  road  construction  and  maintenance,  and  improving  road  safety. 
Moreover,  the  strategy  should  review  the  need  to  maintain  and  improve  the  existing  road 
network  in  areas  with  low  population  densities.  A  Road  Master  Plan  prepared  with  ADB 
assistance8 and approved by the Government identified priority road sections for investment and 
improvement,  but  the  Road  Master  Plan  needs  updating  as  many  priority  projects  identified 
have been constructed or are under construction. 
 
21. 
The  Government  plans,  with  external  assistance,  to  develop  a  new  transport  sector 
strategy and update the Road Master Plan based on the country’s development priority and the 
availability of financial resources. The new transport sector strategy will, among others, assess 
total  funding  requirements  to  maintain  the  existing  road  network,  identify  major  funding 
constraints, and recommend how to address these constraints over the medium term. A working 
group, chaired jointly by ADB and the World Bank, was established in April 2004 to coordinate 
assistance to the Government in preparing the transport sector strategy. Over the medium term, 
the  Government  accords  high  priority  to  developing  the  country’s  two  key  road  corridors:  
(i)  a  north-south  corridor  linking  Mongolia  with  the  PRC  and  Russia,  and  (ii)  an  east-west 
corridor (i.e., the millennium road) linking several aimag centers with Ulaanbaatar.

TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR AWARENESS AND 
PREVENTION OF HIV/AIDS AND HUMAN TRAFFICKING 

Background and Rationale 

A. 
 
Mongolia  is  at  the  early  stage  of  HIV/AIDS1 epidemics  with  only  four  registered  cases 
1. 
transmitted  mainly  through  sexual  contact.2 However,  the  country  is  vulnerable  to  HIV/AIDS 
diseases  due  to  the  high-risk  behavior  among  young  population,  an  increasing  number  of  sex 
workers  with  poor  condom  use,  high  prevalence  of  sexually  transmitted  infections  (STIs),  and 
rapidly  growing  HIV/AIDS  diseases  in  neighboring  countries.  With  high  poverty  incidence, 
women  are  disproportionately  vulnerable  to  HIV/AIDS  and  trafficking  for  prostitution. 
Systematic trafficking cases have been reported.3 
 
2. 
The Regional Road Development  Project will build the remaining section of Mongolia’s 
north-south road transport corridor between Choyr and the border with the People’s Republic of 
China  (PRC)  in  Zamyn-Uud 4  to  link  the  Asian  highway  networks  of  the  PRC  and  Russia.  
The  Project  can  have  a  significant  impact  on  the  spread  of  HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking 
because  of  a  large  number  of  workers  employed  during  construction  and  the  increased 
movement of passengers across the borders with the PRC and Russia after project completion.5 
The technical assistance (TA) will mitigate potential risks of HIV/AIDS transmission and human 
trafficking along the north-south road corridor. 
 
B. 

Objectives and Scope 

The goal of the TA is to reduce the risks of HIV/AIDS and human trafficking that may be 
3. 
associated  with  the  construction  of  the  project  road  and  operation  of  the  north-south  road 
transport  corridor  after  project  completion.  The  purposes  of  the  TA  are  to  (i)  raise  public 
awareness  of  HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking;  (ii)  address  the  risk  of  HIV/AIDS  transmission 
among  construction  workers,  sex  workers,  local  communities,  truck  drivers,  and  other  road 
users; and (iii) strengthen border control capacity against human trafficking.  
 
4. 
To achieve these objectives, the short-term strategy will focus on (i) creating awareness 
of  HIV/AIDS  including  the  transmission  channel  of  drug  use,  and  human  trafficking  among 
construction  workers,  sex  workers,  and  local  communities;  (ii)  promoting  behavior  change;  
(iii)  promoting  use  of  condoms;  (iv)  implementing  STI/HIV/AIDS  prevention  services,  including 
STI treatment and voluntary counseling and testing services at construction camps and in local 
communities; and (v) enhancing STI/HIV/AIDS monitoring. The long-term strategy will focus on 
(i)  building  HIV/AIDS  prevention  capacity  of  communities  along  the  north-south  road  and  at 
borders;  (ii)  promoting  awareness  of  HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking  among  business 
communities  (particularly  construction  companies,  transport  operators,  and  hotels),  border 
authorities, and media; and (iii) strengthening border control and establishing a regional network 
among  Mongolia,  the  PRC,  and  Russia  for  prevention  of  HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking.  
The TA will contribute to the achievement of the long-term strategy. 

                                                 
1  HIV/AIDS = human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. 
2  The  Joint  United  Nations  Program  on  HIV/AIDS  estimates  that  about  300  persons  might  be  infected  with  HIV  in 

Mongolia by the end of 2003.  

3  An attempted trafficking of over 400 Mongolian girls was recently reported in the UB Post on 30 January 2004. 
4  In 2001, there were 1.4 million inbound and outbound passengers in Mongolia, of whom 50% traveled via Zamyn-

Uud, 16% via Suhbaatar, and the rest through other border posts. 

5  Mobile populations are among the main transmitters of HIV/AIDS infection. Construction workers, transport workers, 

truck drivers, and traders compose key mobile groups.

D. 

Implementation Arrangements 

8. 
The Ministry of Health will be the Executing Agency and will implement the TA in close 
coordination  with  DOR.  The  project  implementation  unit  (PIU)  of  the  ADB-assisted  Second 
Health Sector Development Project (Loan 1998) will be the Implementing Agency. A full-time TA 
coordinator will be appointed at the PIU, and two small offices with part-time assistants will be 
set  up  at  the  health  departments  of  Govisumber  and  Dornogovi  aimags  in  Choyr  and 
Saynshand, respectively. A steering committee at the national level will be established to guide 
TA  implementation.  The  steering  committee  will  be  chaired  by  a  vice  minister  of  health  and 
comprise  representatives  of  the  PIU  of  the  Second  Health  Sector  Development  Project,  DOR, 
ministries of health and justice and home affairs, the General Customs Office, and an existing 
technical  expert  group.  Advisory  groups  will  also  be  set  up  at  local  levels,  chaired  by  the 
governors’ offices and comprising representatives of aimag health and road departments, local 
transport  operators,  local  police,  border  and  customs  officers,  local  communities,  and  relevant 
NGOs. The TA is expected to begin in February 2005 and be completed in July 2009. 
 
The  TA  will  provide  1.5  person-months  of  international  and  160  person-months  of 
9. 
domestic  consulting  services.  The 
international  consultant  should  have  expertise  and 
experience  in  anti-human  trafficking.  The  domestic  consultants  should  have  expertise  in  anti-
human  trafficking,  health  education  and  advocacy,  HIV/AIDS/STI  medical  services,  and 
epidemiological  surveillance  and  monitoring.  The  consultants  will  be  recruited  individually 
according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory 
to  ADB  for  selecting  and  engaging  domestic  consultants.  Equipment,  supplies,  and  materials 
under the TA will be procured following ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. The equipment will 
be turned over to the Executing Agency or local governments after TA completion. The PIU of 
the  Second  Health  Sector  Development  Project  will  provide  administrative  support  to  the 
consultants.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 

The economic analysis1 of the Project was based on a comparison of with- and without- 
1. 
project cases. The analysis uses 2003 economic prices2 and covers the period of 2006−2025, 
comprising 3 years of construction and 17 years of operation. 
 
A. 
 
2. 
was used for making traffic forecasts:  
 

Traffic forecasts for the project road were  made for 2006−2025. A three-stage process 

Traffic Forecast 

Initial  traffic  forecasts  were  based  on  an  analysis  of  macro  level  demographic 
and economic trends for Mongolia, as well as for the corridor between Choyr and 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) border in Zamyn-Uud. 

Macro  level  forecasts  for  freight  and  passenger  traffic  between  Choyr  and 
Zamyn-Uud  were  disaggregated  into  road  and  rail  transport,  based  on  the  data 
gathered from interviews, traffic surveys, and published reports and statistics on 
recent and anticipated modal shares. 

Based  on  traffic  survey  data  and  actual  traffic  patterns  along  the  project  road, 
road  traffic  projections  were  further  disaggregated  into  three  types  of  traffic:  
(a)  normal  traffic,  or  existing  traffic  in  the  absence  of  the  Project,  (b)  generated 
traffic,  or  traffic  that  develops  due  to  reduced  transport  costs  or  increased 
business  activities  in  the  project  area,  and  (c)  diverted  traffic,  or  traffic  that  is 
diverted from the existing railway to the project road. 

 
3. 
Mongolia’s gross domestic product (GDP) and population are projected to grow by 4.5% 
and 0.95% per annum, respectively, during 2006−2025. GDP and population growth projections 
are  largely  in  line  with  recent  growth  rates.  Based  on  economic  and  demographic  growth 
projections, traffic for the corridor between Choyr and the PRC border in Zamyn-Uud is forecast 
to  grow  by  6.3%  for  freight  traffic  in  ton-kilometers  (TKM)  and  5.1%  for  passenger  traffic  in 
passenger-kilometers  (PKM)  per  annum  during  2006−2025  (Table  A12.1).  The  growth  rate  of 
projected traffic is higher than that of GDP because the transport intensity of the economy has 
increased in recent years with freight transport intensity growing at a faster rate than passenger 
transport intensity.3 
 
4. 
Transport  between  Choyr  and  Zamyn-Uud  is  by  road  and  rail.  Based  on  the  existing 
modal shares and an analysis of traffic patterns derived from traffic surveys,4 projected corridor 
traffic  was  disaggregated  into  road  and  rail  modes  (Table  A12.1).  The  railway  is  projected  to 
remain  the  dominant  mode  of  transport,  although  its  shares  in  terms  of  TKM  and  PKM  are 
expected  to  decrease  gradually.  The  road  is  projected  to  attract  traffic,  particularly  passenger 
traffic from 2009, the first year of operation of the project road. The road’s share is projected to 
increase from 3.7% to 23.8% in PKM and 0.4% to 5.8% in TKM during 2006−2025.

4  Factors  such  as  commodity  type,  distance,  and  cost  for  freight  transport,  and  distance  and  cost  for  passenger

Based on the projected corridor traffic, traffic surveys5 conducted along the project road 
5. 
alignment  in  August−September  2003,  and  the  data  provided  by  the  Department  of  Roads, 
traffic  forecasts  for  with-  and  without-  project  cases  were  made  (Table  A12.2).  In  the  without-
project case, traffic would continue to move along the existing multiple unimproved earth tracks 
(normal  traffic).  The  average  daily  traffic  (ADT)  will  remain  relatively  low,  from  288  vehicles  in 
2006 to 864 vehicles in 2025. In the with-project case, ADT will increase significantly from 2009 
since  the  road  will  create  diverted  and  generated  traffic.  ADT  is  projected  to  grow  from  288 
vehicles in 2006 to 3,075 vehicles in 2025. Regional traffic (i.e., traffic from and to Mongolia and 
transit  traffic  via  Mongolia)  is  projected  to  constitute  the  bulk  of  total  traffic,  with  its  share 
growing from 30% in 2006 to 75% in 2025. 
 
B. 
 
6. 
There  are  four  ways  of  meeting  the  projected  road  traffic  between  Choyr  and  Zamyn-
Uud: (i) construction of a asphalt concrete road; (ii) construction of a road with double bitumen 
surface treatment (DBST) surface; (iii) construction of a gravel road; and (iv) expansion of the 
capacity  of  the  existing  railway  instead  of  constructing  the  project  road,  given  that  the 
preliminary  alignment  for  the  project  road  roughly  parallels  the  railway  line.  An  alternatives 
analysis was undertaken to select the most appropriate project alternative. 
 
7. 
Costs  and  benefits  of  the  project  alternatives  used  a  domestic  price  numeraire  with  a 
shadow  exchange  rate  factor  of  1.07  (based  on  the  2002  data)  to  estimate  foreign  exchange 
effects.  Costs  were  divided  into  tradable  and  nontradable  materials,  equipment,  skilled  labor, 
and unskilled labor. A composite conversion factor of 1.0078 was used to express the Project’s 
capital  costs  as  economic  costs  (Table  A12.3  explains  the  computation  of  the  composite

 Appendix 12 

 51

Economic  benefits  consist  of  savings  on  transport  costs  and  travel  time  for  freight  and 
8. 
passenger  traffic,  which  are  valued  in  terms  of  (i)  vehicle  operating  cost  (VOC)  savings  for 
normal traffic, (ii) difference in cost and travel time of using the railway and the project road for 
diverted traffic, and (iii) 50% of VOC savings from normal traffic as proxy for willingness to pay 
for generated traffic. Transport cost savings embody the value of time saved by vehicle drivers 
and crews, but not by passengers or cargo. The value of time saved by passengers traveling to 
work was calculated at $0.50 per hour. For passengers traveling for leisure, 25% of the value of 
the work time saved is used as proxy for willingness to pay for a nonbusiness trip. The value of 
time saved for freight is estimated at $0.16 per ton per day, based on an average value of $500 
per ton at a 12% opportunity cost of capital. 
 
9. 
The  alternatives  analysis  was  carried  out  in  two  phases.  On  the  first  level,  the  three 
alternatives  for  the  project  road  were  compared  to  determine  the  appropriate  type  of  road 
surface. The results (Table A12.4) show that the gravel road option has the lowest value, with 
an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  26.4%  and  net  present  value  (NPV)  of  $68.2 
million. In terms of EIRR, the highest value is for the DBST road option (30.4%) and the second 
highest  value  is  for  the  asphalt  concrete  road  option  (29.7%).  In  terms  of  NPV,  the  asphalt 
concrete road option ($131.3 million) shows a higher value than the DBST road option ($121.9 
million). In view of NPV and given that the project road forms part of the Asian highway network 
and other sections of the north-south road corridor between Altanbulag and Choyr are asphalt 
concrete,  the  asphalt  concrete  road  option  appears  a  better  choice  than  the  DBST  option.  
On  the  second  level,  comparison  is  made  between  the  asphalt  concrete  road  option  and  the 
railway  option.  The  results  show  that  the  railway  alternative  has  a  lower  EIRR  value  (19.7%) 
and  NPV  ($59.1  million),  and  is  thus  less  economically  feasible.  Based  on  the  alternatives 
analysis,  development  of  an  asphalt  concrete  road  between  Choyr  and  the  PRC  border  in 
Zamyn-Uud is the economically efficient option for increasing transport capacity on this corridor.

Benefits of the Project 

C. 
 
10. 
The Project’s primary benefit is transport cost savings due to the improved road surface 
roughness7 and resultant increases in vehicle speeds. Transport cost savings are estimated to 
account for 96% of the total project benefits. For nine types of vehicles, the Project is expected 
to result in an average VOC reduction of 43.1% per unit traveling between Choyr and the PRC 
border in Zamyn-Uud, ranging between 36.1% per car and 45.5% per heavy bus (Table A12.5). 
The benefits from VOC savings, which initially accrue to vehicle owners and operators, will be 
shared  gradually  with  users  of  road  transport  services  through  reduced  freight  rates  and 
passenger fares.

11. 
The  project  benefits  include  savings  on  travel  time  because  of  the  relatively  straight 
alignment of the project road and increased vehicle speeds. The Project is expected to reduce 
the average travel time between Choyr and the PRC border in Zamyn-Uud by 56%, from 13.4

but  such  benefits  are  not  quantifiable  and  thus  are  not  included  in  the  economic  analysis.  
The  Project  is  not  designed  to  alleviate  traffic  congestion  since  congestion  is  generally  not  a 
concern in Mongolia’s road sector, except for Ulaanbaatar during the rush hours on workdays.

Sensitivity Analysis 

D. 
 
12. 
Sensitivity analysis was undertaken to identify the parameters to which the EIRR of the 
Project is sensitive. The results (Table A12.7) indicate that the EIRR of the Project exceeds the 
cutoff  level  of  12%,  except  when  (i)  the  Project’s  capital  costs  increase  by  214%,  (ii)  road 
maintenance costs increase by 1,139%, (iii) the surface roughness of the project road during the 
dry  season  increase  by  175%,  and  (iv)  traffic  growth  or  user  benefits  are  reduced  by  66%.  
Even  when  diverted  traffic  is  reduced  by  100%,  the  cutoff  level  of  12%  will  not  be  reached. 
Eliminating routine and periodic maintenance on the project road will cause deterioration of road 
conditions, which will significantly reduce user benefits because of increased VOC. An increase 
in  the  roughness  index  of  the  project  road  to  19.8  will  reduce  the  EIRR  to  12%.  A  high 
roughness  coefficient  can  only  be  experienced  if  the  project  road  is  not  maintained  for  a 
considerable  period  of  time.  This  is  unlikely  to  occur  because  appropriate  measures  are 
included  in  the  Project  to  ensure  that  adequate  funding  is  available  for  maintenance  of  the 
project road.

E. 
 
13. 
Risk analysis examined the probability distribution of the estimated EIRR and NPV of the 
Project. Within the assumed range of parameter estimates, the probability that the EIRR of the 
Project or NPV of the Project is negative is 26%. The median EIRR of the Project is 14.7%, with 
a  range  of  0.5%−31.5%,  and  the  medium  NPV  amounts  to  $22.7  million,  with  a  range  of 
negative $110.9 million to $152.2 million. 
 
F. 
 
14. 
Distribution analysis was based on trade statistics and the data collected from interviews 
and surveys of passengers, freight companies, and customs officials. Two types of distribution 
analysis  were  carried  out  to  assess  the  distribution  of  project  benefits:  (i)  among  regional 
economies, and (ii) among various stakeholders within Mongolia. The results are summarized in 
Table  A12.8.  The  Project  will  result  in  total  net  project  benefits  of  $268.3  million,  comprising 
$235.7 million for Mongolia, $29.4 million for the PRC, and $3.2 million for Russia. Based on the 
proximity  and  established  traffic  patterns,  90%  and  10%  of  the  project  benefits  that  do  not 
accure  to  Mongolia  are  distributed  between  the  PRC  and  Russia,  respectively.  Mongolia  will 
account for 87.8% of total project benefits, while the PRC and Russia are expected to receive 
11% and 1.2% of total benefits, respectively.

A. 
 
Is the sector identified as a national 
priority in country poverty analysis?   
 
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Mongolia:  
Mongolia is a landlocked country  with per capita gross domestic product (GDP) of $505 in 2003. The Government’s 
poverty standard reflects subsistence  living and is based on a fixed minimum income equivalent ranging from $0.56 
per  day  in  western  Mongolia  to  $0.90  per  day  in  Ulaanbaatar,  the  nation’s  capital.  Approximately  21.6%  of  the 
population  in  the  project  area  (Govisumber  and  Dornogovi  aimags)  live  below  the  poverty  line  according  to 
government estimates. The Project will provide reliable all-weather access to the poor towns and help reduce poverty 
in  the  area  through  (i)  improved  links  to  domestic  and  world  markets;  (ii)  increased  quality,  quantity,  and  variety  of 
goods;  (iii)  increased  job  and  income  opportunities;  (iv)  improved  market  information  and  infrastructure  for  sales, 
warehousing, and distribution; (v) increased private sector investments; (vi) reduced transport time and cost of goods; 
and (vii) increased options for personal travel. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis  
Poverty Classification: Other 
Poverty  in  Mongolia  is  primarily  income-based,  with  a  high  incidence  of  transient  poverty—those  who  live  near  the 
poverty  line. According to local government  data, about 21.6% of the people  in the villages  along the  alignment are 
poor,  of  whom  7%  are  very  poor.  People  living  in  transient  poverty  are  vulnerable  to  external  shocks,  as  they  have 
limited savings, job skills, and social protection against job loss. The official unemployment rate for the project area is 
about  18.4%  (Census  2002),  while  the  project  household  survey  indicated  an  unemployment  rate  of  over  25%.  The 
transition  from  a  socialist  to  a  market  economy  caused  many  Mongolians  in  the  public  sector  and  state-owned 
enterprises to lose their jobs. Some have successfully made a transition to the private sector, but others have fallen 
into poverty due to a lack of job opportunities. The cold weather conditions in the past years caused herders to lose 
their herds and migrate to the towns.  
  
The  Project  will  improve  the  road  transport  infrastructure  needed  for  pro-poor  economic  growth.  Construction  of  the 
project  road  and  the  components  of  cross-border  road  transport  facilitation,  road  safety,  and  area  development 
provide a comprehensive approach to maximizing project benefits to people in the project area. The project road will 
promote  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  by  improving  economic  efficiency,  fostering  trade,  and  facilitating 
regional  cooperation.  Competition  with  the  existing  parallel  railway  will  contribute  to  reducing  passenger  and  freight 
prices.  Lower  transport  costs  will  help  lower  the  prices  of  daily  necessities  in  local  markets  and  enhance  income-
earning opportunities.  
 
Construction  of  the  project  road  will  increase  local  expenditures,  jobs,  and  tax  revenues  that  could  be  used  for 
improving  social  infrastructure  and  services.  The  area  development  component  comprises  (i)  construction  of  four 
access  roads,  (ii)  training  local  laborers  for  road  construction  and  maintenance  jobs,  (iii)  establishment  of  a  pilot 
roadside station, and (iv) the continued stakeholder participation process that includes enhancing small business and 
skills  development.  By  supporting  local  area  development,  the  Project  will  promote  regionally  balanced  economic 
growth  and  social  development.  The  road  safety  improvement  component  and  technical  assistance  (TA)  for 
awareness  and  prevention  of  human  immunodeficiency  virus/acquired  immunodeficiency  syndrome  (HIV/AIDS)  and 
human  trafficking  will  be  implemented  along  the  north-south  road  corridor  to  mitigate  potential  social  risks  and 
strengthen the positive social and poverty reduction impacts of the Project. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
Stakeholder  analysis  during  project  preparation  helped  identify  the  key  project  stakeholders  and  their  interests. 
Numerous  consultation  meetings  were  held  with  government  agencies,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  local 
communities, road construction and maintenance companies, and other external aid agencies. A household survey of 
3%  of  the  project  area  population  was  conducted  in  the  villages  along  the  project  road  alignment.  Stakeholder 
consultations were useful in drawing lessons from previous projects: (i) a local training program on road construction 
will  help  achieve  local  employment  targets;  and  (ii)  a  wide  right-of-way  along  the  project  road  will  help  prevent 
encroachment along the alignment and subsequent strip development and reduce traffic accidents. Consultation with 
local  governments  was  essential  to  reaching  agreement  on  the  road  alignment  and  the  need  for  access  roads. 
Discussions  with  NGOs  confirmed  the  need  to  expand  the  traffic  safety  component  to  cover  the  entire  north-south 
corridor, and to strengthen the human trafficking subcomponent of the TA. 
 
Is there a participation strategy? 
A  stakeholder  participation  process  is  included  in  the  area  development  component.  The  process  will  focus  on  (i) 
continued stakeholder meetings for project design and implementation; (ii) assistance in conducting training for road 
construction and maintenance, including good working conditions; (iii) enhanced small business skills and related job

creation, especially for the poor; (iv) development of a pilot roadside station; (v) facilitation of the implementation of the 
road  safety  improvement  component  among  traffic  police  officers  and  local  communities;  (vi)  involvement  of 
households interested in road maintenance; (vii) assistance with awareness and prevention of HIV/AIDS and human 
trafficking; and (viii) community-based environmental enhancement and monitoring. Aimag and soum governments will 
coordinate with the Department of Roads (DOR) during project implementation. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Traditionally, Mongolia has been a patriarchal society with sharp gender division of responsibilities where women have 
played  a  subordinate  role.  During  the  socialist  period  (1921- 1990),  the  Government  was  committed  to  gender 
equality.  Women  had  equal  opportunity  for  education  and  gained  considerable  ground  in  employment and political 
participation.  As  Mongolia  moves  toward  a  market  economy,  women  begin  to  face  greater  difficulty  in  the  labor 
market,  at  home,  and  in  politics.  With  higher  education,  wives  achieve  a  higher  status  than  their  husbands.  The 
situation lead to friction and instability in marriages. About 30% household heads are women.  
 
A  gender  plan  is  not  necessary,  as  measures  to  promote  women’s  participation  and  mitigate  potentially  negative 
impacts  on  women  are  integrated  into  various  project  components  and  assurances.  Through  the  stakeholder 
participation process under the area development component, the needs  of women and other vulnerable groups will 
be addressed. The Project will encourage women’s participation in planning and developing the pilot roadside station. 
Women  will  benefit  from  the  Project  and  will  have  equal  access  to  project-created  jobs  and  wages.  The  Project  will 
generate additional revenue, which can be used to improve social infrastructure and services.

There  will  be  no  tolls  along  the  project  road,  except  near  the 
border  with  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  in  Zamyn-
Uud.  All  licensed  motorized  vehicles  will  be  able  to  use  the 
road.  The  Project  will  reduce  travel  time  and  transport  costs, 
with savings passed on to the users of road transport services 
and  reduced  prices  of  daily  necessities  for  local  consumers. 
The Project will make road transport services more affordable 
to a greater portion of the population. 
The Project will help reduce unemployment through job creation 
and  skills  development.  Local  laborers  will  be  trained  for  road 
construction and maintenance work. Poor households along the 
alignment  will  receive  priority  for  road  maintenance  jobs.  DOR 
will  ensure  that  contractors  follow  labor  laws.  The  Mongolian 
Professional  Inspectorate  will  monitor  labor  conditions  at 
construction camps. 
Ethnic  minority  groups  comprise  about  3.5%  of  the  population 
in the project area. They do not face discrimination and are not 
considered  vulnerable.  The  Project  will  not  adversely  affect 
seminomadic  herders.  It  will  help  improve  the  viability  of  the 
local  livestock  industry  with  improved  access  to  markets  and 
increases  in  domestic  and  regional  demands  for  livestock 
products. 
HIV/AIDS  and  Human  Trafficking:  The Project will complete 
the  north-south  corridor  to  link  Russia  and  the  PRC  via 
Mongolia.  The  Project  could  contribute  to  the  spread  of 
HIV/AIDS  and  human  trafficking.  The  TA  associated  with  the 
loan  will  help  reduce  the  risk  of  HIV/AIDS  transmission,  and 
raise awareness and strengthen border control capacity against 
human  trafficking.  Contractors  will  be  required  to  distribute 
information on HIV/AIDS to workers.
